text: My question is...in the 1930's we have had the hottest temperatures recorded (NOAH). Back then we didn't have millions of cars, thousands of factories, etc. We had more fires in north and south America that ever, etc. What caused that? And if those time frames were to be included in the many climate studies that seem to choose the 60's as starting points, the actual climate change would appear much less significant if not in the other direction as the climate alarmist would like you to believe. I certainly hope that a number of climatology alarmists and politicians aren't deceiving us for their personal gain...funding, or political ambitions. My opinion is that if we want to become a third world country all we need to do is eliminate our dependable current energy sources and switch to wind, solar, etc. which at this point in time cannot come close to fulfilling our energy needs. If I had to choose between some pollution (maybe our goals should be to make our energy suppliers better and better) and being a third world country (and, I have been to some of those countries and can assure you that you don't want to become one), I will take a chance on improving our present energy situation such as we have done with cars... if you were in L.A. in the sixties and seventies you would have seen how awful it was and would realize we adapt extremely well.

text:
Salts Math When a disaster happens in the US, it generally causes a lot more damage than when it happens in a poor country like Haiti.  But the loss of life is almost always worse in the poor country.  Why is that?  Because more expensive stuff exists in the US.  
As economies expand, there are more expensive things generally.  Therefore, any disaster will do more damage than the same disaster would have in the past.  
It should also be noted that if a country‚Äôs population grows without a corresponding improvement in building standards and emergency preparedness, more people will be at risk during a disaster.  Which would cause more loss of life, LA getting hit by an extremely severe earthquake or a small town in Alaska experiencing the same earthquake?  
It seems to me that there IS more stuff out there, and there‚Äôs also more people.  
Do you have evidence that the actual severity of storms, as measured by wind speed and rainfall is getting more severe?  And further, how far back does this evidence go, since comparing one year to the next proves nothing?
author: daer devvyl

text:
James Pyke I‚Äôll try to wade through all this information.  Thanks for that.  
I don‚Äôt feel every climate scientist is liberal.  And I certainly don‚Äôt believe that unemployed people are funding them.  
I believe that generally universities have been taken over by some pretty radical people, and so they are more likely to graduate people in all fields if they conform to some very leftwing ideas.  I also believe that the mainstream media is very biased, which causes them to report on climate issues (and other things) in the most alarmist fashion possible.  Findings and predictions are exaggerated, and only the scientists with the most radical views are given any exposure.  I also believe that some scientists with opposing (or at least more moderate views) stay quiet, or go into other fields of study altogether, because they are afraid of being called ‚Äúclimate change deniers‚Äù if they don‚Äôt conform to the required views on climate change.  
I‚Äôm also a bit curious about your repeated statements that Shapiro gets funding from the Koch family, to the point that you keep calling him a ‚ÄúKoch employee.‚Äù  I‚Äôm not saying necessarily that you are wrong about the funding issue, but can you tell me how you know this?  It seems like the kind of thing that some people would throw out without any proof.  And even if it was true, it‚Äôs still dishonest to refer to Shapiro and others as employees of the Koch family, for the same reason that it‚Äôs unfair to refer to Democratic politicians as employees of unions or Planned Parenthood if they get donations from those institutions.  
I will actually agree with you that an organization calling themselves a free speech club should have a wide range of speakers, including ones that I disagree with.  But the other side of this argument is that leftist ideas already get ample exposure on college campi, and so they simply promote ideas that may be more difficult to hear on campus.

text:
¬†@daer devvyl¬† ¬†Some older IPCC models underestimated the warming. As did some older reputable models. Most of them are pretty accurate. https://www.carbonbrief.org/analysis-how-well-have-climate-models-projected-global-warming. Here is a peer-reviewed reference: https://agupubs.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/full/10.1002/2015GL064888

The increase of intensity of hurricanes in the North Atlantic since 1970 is "virtually certain" per the IPCC AR5. But attribution is "low confidence." https://www.ipcc.ch/site/assets/uploads/2018/02/WG1AR5_SPM_FINAL.pdf¬†

William Nordhaus is the economists' name. Shapiro was wrong about what he found. Nordhaus' Nobel prize-winning model shows 3.5 degrees C of warming is the value where costs meet the benefits, and he believes in implementing a carbon tax of about $.50/per gallon of gas immediately (https://www.pnas.org/content/114/7/1518 figure 1). Also see https://www.forbes.com/sites/howardgleckman/2018/10/10/bill-nordhaus-the-nobel-prize-climate-change-and-carbon-taxes/#46d584e6a03d

author: douglas johns

text:
1. ‚Äúmodeling has been wrong for 20-30 years‚Äù

This is either an accidental or intentional omission of a key detail about climate modeling. Scientists actually accurately predicted how much the earth was going to warm over the next couple of decades, but 90% of the heat was absorbed by the ocean. This will eventually catch up to us as ocean currents bring that heat to the surface and it becomes absorbed into the atmosphere.

2. ‚Äúwater level will rise a predictable number of feet‚Äù

Another omission of a key detail. The actual water level isn‚Äôt so much a problem as when tropical storms interact with the higher waters levels, causing more damaging flooding and storm surges. And also I‚Äôll add, when Mr. Shapiro says that this will cause humans to migrate as they‚Äôve always done, I wonder how he‚Äôll react when millions of climate migrants from poor countries in the third world come knocking on the door of the US. I wonder if he‚Äôll liberalize his stance on immigration and advocate for allowing these people fleeing a problem that the US and other rich western countries are largely responsible for entry, or if he‚Äôll advocate for tightening up immigration. (can‚Äôt imagine it will be the former.)

3. ‚Äúhurricanes aren‚Äôt getting more intense, humans are just developing more in the path of hurricanes‚Äù

The part about development is true but the part about hurricanes is utterly false. Climatologists consistently find that climate change is causing hurricanes to move slower and drop more rain, both of which causes more catastrophic flooding, which is what makes hurricanes disastrous‚Äî such as the case with Hurricane Harvey. Shapiro says hurricanes aren‚Äôt becoming more common which is true, but nobody who knows anything is actually arguing that. They are arguing that destructive hurricanes are becoming more common. Same goes for wildfires‚Äî scientists consistently find that climate change is making the conditions for destructive wildfires much more common.

4. ‚Äúit‚Äôs more costly to intervene than to do anything‚Äù

I‚Äôm not familiar with the academic Shapiro cites so I‚Äôm not going to address him. However, this is such a bold claim to be making without giving a disclaimer on how complex and debates this issue is. (Not to mention the countless studies and scientists that fight fiercely against these claims.) There are too many unknowns with how fast climate change will start affecting the US to know whether economic growth will outpace growing disaster costs (however, a CBO report found that costs related to hurricane damage will grow at a faster rate than the US‚Äôs GDP, a factor of both climate change and development). However what‚Äôs clear is how much climate change will cost‚Äî for instance, should we build a $25 billion sea wall around NYC that may become obsolete within decades or spend much more to relocate huge parts of the city? How about billions of dollars doing controlled burns, thinning forests, and fighting fires, not to mention the lives risked and lost to fight the fires? And then the struggles over who‚Äôs going to pay for these initiatives arises. Should states fund all of it (they can‚Äôt)? If not, then the federal govt will have to cover part of it, but why would midwesterners have to pay tax dollars to fund relocations and sea walls on the coasts, and why would coast dwellers have to pay for wildfires? There is a huge amount of nuance Shapiro is just skating over here.

5. ‚Äúthe US has done the most of any country to reduce emissions‚Äù

Technically true but implying that all countries are equally responsible for climate change and thus the US is doing the best on climate change is completely rediculous. China and India contribute as much/more to climate change than the US currently, but taking into account historical emissions, the US and other rich western countries have contributed much more to climate change as a whole because they‚Äôve been industrialized much longer. Thus they have a much greater responsibility to mitigate than poor industrializing countries.

At least Shapiro admitted at the beginning that he wasn‚Äôt an expert. That much he got right.

text: Can‚Äôt understand the basis for the skeptics claim that the models are unreliable. The mean average of climate modelling done since the 1970s tracks with the observed heating right up to the present day.  The early modelling done back in 1973 estimated a 0.6 degree rise up to 2000, the observed range for 2000 was a rise of between 0.51 and 0.56 degrees. Very close to the 73 model and baring in mind improvements in computational power and refinements in the science over the last five decades the models are reliable and the need to take action and transition away from fossil fuels is clear.

The truth is that earth climate has always changed a lot, and often quickly. Our ~200year Eurocentric regional baseline is hardly a good benchmark. Especially when considering centuries, millennia, or other regions of the world.

About the science, the ‚ÄúScientific Method‚Äù does actually work by consensus, through peer review, and it approximates ‚Äútruth‚Äù and ‚Äúfact‚Äù as asymptotic values. Many widely accepted ideas have been later debunked, and some astoundingly wrong ideas have yielded correct inferences. For example on gravity, Newton was right, Einstein was right. Einstein was just more right. Worse yet, we also know that Einstein was wrong, too, we just don‚Äôt have better answers yet. There‚Äôs actually very little in Science that‚Äôs solid enough to be ‚Äúlaw‚Äù.

text: Shapiro is wrong when he says that climate modelling has been over estimating the amount of climate change that is taking place. Media articles may misrepresent the science, which may give ignorant people that impression, but the requirements set out by the IPCC are based on modelling that underestimates climate change. We recently reached 1.1 degree of global average increase and now we are at 1.3 degrees. Given the huge times al lags in the manifestation of temperature increase, 2 degrees is already locked in. But the economics who influence the IPCC reporting have pushed for underestimated results to be relied upon. And therefore the 1.5 degree target is not only not achievable, it never was to begin with because it underestimated future warming from emissions that had then already been emitted. Shapiro clearly does not understand this issue at all.

text:
I love freedom of speech because then I can call this shit out.

I love how Ben Shapiro claims that "conservativitism" is about "personal responsibility", yet when it comes to climate change "it's not economically feasible until it hits 3.5 degrees", like that's the only reason for stopping climate change. If you were about personal responsibillity, you would be about making the personally responsible decision for your future self, your children and others. His version of libertarianism and neo-classical economics is about "lets get wealthy cos it's fun, and maybe we'll use put the toys towards something useful in the future, but only when it's absolutely necessary". 

He refuses to move past neoclassical economics, which has been debunked relentlessly due to it's assumptions that a) people are rational beings and will spend money in our own best interests and b) that we will be able to "wealth" our way out of every problem. People are not rational human beings. We smoke, drink, fuck our neighbours wives. And why? Because we are selfish and it feels good, not because we know that smoking will cause us lung cancer in the next 30 years.

If we go by the mentality of "oh, we'll build our way out of it" and "it's not economically feasible now" we are essentially no better than a 13 year old boy procrastinating doing his maths homework. Sure it would be a better investment in the future to do his homework now, but right now, it's a better investment to go and make friends because his priorities are on being cool. Similarly, the carbon emitting companys' priority is on money and power, and all the joys of life that come from that. 


Why should we give a fuck about climate change? Well because of food. Agricultural yields are incredibly temperature sensitive. If we want to make sure the price of food stays down, we need to reduce our emissions. If you don't want to be paying an extra $2 dollars for every loaf of bread you buy, then you need to start investing in energy that comes from renewable farms. The more demand for that goes up, the more supply will and it will drive the price down.

¬†@1thegreatskull¬† The amount of ice which has melted has increased at a far greater rate than ever before in modern human history, which directly correlates to raising CO2 since industrial revolution. Less white ice is reflecting the sun also, something we can clearly track in locations like Iceland, which is accelerating the process even further.

Huge global deforestation is also adding to the problem. On top of that, water pollution and overfishing is ‚Äúbleaching‚Äù the coral reefs around the world year after year and killing off sea life, both of which the world relies on to maintain constant temperature.

That doesn't make any sense. Climate change has been used by scientists since 1956 when physicist, Gilbert Plass published the paper "The Carbon Dioxide Theory of Climatic Change". https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/abs/10.1111/j.2153-3490.1956.tb01206.x

The term global warming didn't come until much later when, in 1975, geochemist Wallace Broecker of Columbia University's Lamont-Doherty Geological Observatory published his paper: "Climatic Change: Are We on the Brink of a Pronounced Global Warming? https://science.sciencemag.org/content/189/4201/460

It's conservative media that keeps repeating this foolish talking point. Thanks to Conservative strategist, Frank Luntz! https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Frank_Luntz

text: There is no evidence whatsoever that CO2 has any effect on the Earth's climate. The Vostock ice-core samples show that climate drives CO2 levels by altering the oceans' ability to sequester CO2, not the other way around. They just assume that you'll jump to the wrong conclusion about that and never step in to correct that false assumption. They're lying to us! Carbon dioxide is a trace atmospheric gas that has no effect on the climate, period. The whole thing is a money-driven hoax perpetrated by con-men in lab coats and the "climate change" that we've seen is simply the Earth coming out of the "Little Ice Age" and the 1940-to-1975 cool period, that's all. The whole lot of them belong in jail...

text: Here is a little more information about the climate change argument.  From a chemistry standpoint, the amount of carbon on this planet is static.  Our earth is a closed system.  No carbon is leaving the earth (excluding rockets) and no carbon is arriving to earth.  Technically, carbon is just constantly going through a chemical reaction and cycle.  All the oil that is underground was some form of carbon based organism.  It is the most renewable energy that we have today.  It takes very little energy to extract and has a lot of potential energy.  Compare that with battery.  Lithium and other exotic metals are hard to find and involve scrape mining.  The damage to the earth is extreme and the ability to recycle is very limited.  So far, I believe in the goal of clean air and water to live comfortably.  There is more of a problem of clean water in India and Africa from human feces than CO2 coming from a modern car.  The same people that petition against global warming brought us CFLs.

text:
As Ben said at the beginning, "I am not a climatologist".  Accordingly I do not accept his opinion over that of scientists who study this constantly.  The Paris Climate Accords were not signed off by 197 nations because they did not think it is serious.  The climate models today are far more accurate than they have been in the past and suggest that we have a lot of problems waiting for us unless we do something to mitigate the problem.
His glib answer about people moving to higher ground as the sea level rises ignores the fact that many of these people have much of their net worth tied up in their housing.  Who is going to buy their houses when the sea is lapping at the front door?
On the bright side, he did not discount human induced global warming completely like many Republicans.

text:
If we want to effectively tackle these problems, what we need is to focus only on measures that have a real impact

1) distance tax: a tax that increases the longer the goods are shipped or transported- this incentivizes a local economy and stops the mess of goods running around the world for no reason.

2) female education- the more educated the less children they will have, as overpopulation is a huge problem

3) tackle income inequality- tax the super wealthy and the multinationals, make them pay the right share, no more tax avoidance or producing in countries with lower regulations. Big companies need the most resources and make up the biggest polluters, so local and smaller is better.

4) universal basic income so people dont have "to make a living" at any cost and follow their passions- no damaging, stupid or unnecessary work

5) make hemp biodiesel (and other biodiesels) make up 30% of all fuel compulsory in the economy and make investments. Tackle food waste and make it maximal 5% of all produced. Go towards 0% fossil fuels with improved technology. Swap most plastics for hemp-derived materials

6) sustainability index- make an index of the worst environmental offender-practices. Ban those that are not needed and bring within limits those that can be made sustainable. Use taxes to incentivize/disincentivize

7) go towards a bio-adapted infrastructure such as passages for the wild under highways and so forth. Go back to natural farming, drop all intensive farming, is healthier anyway. Decrease production of animal products. Abandon chemicals, fertilizers and pesticides, all not sustainable.¬†

8) we need a working UN back in some form, to protect areas such as the amazonas and other strategically important parts of the world for the ecology. Besides that we need first nation countries to invest in countries that are lagging behind, as the investment would yield much greater results. This is a global challenge.

9) drop all the measures that wont make any difference and accept that we cant control it 100% at this point. Maybe there are some benefits in a warmer climate too.

Feel free to copy/paste

text:
Sir David Attenborough has said that reforesting our lands and feeding our populations with better food using modern technology is the best solution for ourselves and our planet. 

https://youtu.be/c3bdUk4qa0Y

Many people have believed the carbon dioxide demon when the truth is quite evidently right in front of their eyes. The stripping of forests for plantations and habitats has changed the climate. 

The planet‚Äôs climate has been controlled by life forms for 3 billion years as seen by earths carbon dioxide level of a mere 0.04% against our two neighbours mars and Venus that have 90%+ carbon dioxide. The burgeoning human population struggled to feed its own with grains that caused forests that bound soils and moisture to be ripped up and replaced with dry fields with no topsoil retention. So plant life‚Äôs grip on the climate was weakened and the climate shifted slightly. 

The solution is to return the forests and feed the population at the same time. New plant factories in the Netherlands (53¬∞N) are able to compete with agriculture in the tropics to produce our food in a fraction of the space and with a fraction of the water required by conventional agriculture.

Build plant factories to feed 7.8 billion people and liberate land and water for forests
https://youtu.be/dnCQuwCtqJg
https://youtu.be/qGyAeqdkkbw
https://youtu.be/ESuzrY2abAw

See examples of working plant factories
https://youtu.be/5clOYWsNhhk
https://youtu.be/4CMfPLEtQMQ

Use cattle herds to revitalise soil
https://youtu.be/vpTHi7O66pI

Use goats to reduce fire dangers in forests
https://youtu.be/g9yiclBCxMo 

Use agrivoltaics to turn deserts into meadows with solar panels
https://youtu.be/XwFB22r9zRo
https://youtu.be/CS3bBO05fpU

Use marine cloud seeding to moisten and seed ocean air for clouds and rain
https://youtu.be/Awf1W0-UMR4

Use minerals to assist salmon populations 
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Haida_Salmon_Restoration_Corporation

Don‚Äôt be misanthropic. Be positive. Be useful. Help flora and fauna control climate and don‚Äôt demonise plant food (carbon dioxide).

It‚Äôs now possible with plant factories to make a country like Britain self-sufficient in food and return its arable land to forests. It just requires the focus of resources.

The individual can also help reducing the rape of forests by moving away from grains into plant and animal fats and proteins with the keto diet and live longer and healthier lives.

text: The problem I have seen with the debate on whether the climate on earth is warming exponentially caused by humans versus the earth goes through natural cycles and is always changing, is that the vast majority of the scientists who claim that humans cause the climate to warm and if nothing changes all of our coasts will be under water by, insert date here, are funded by the government in one way or another. I didn‚Äôt give a specific year because since the late 80s, that specific date continues to change. Once we reach the previous prediction for when our coasts will be under water or the polar caps will be ice free or we won‚Äôt be witnessing snowfall anymore, they change said date. This has happened a half dozen times now. The scientists who believe that we go through natural cycles, I‚Äôve found not to be funded by government. Both hypothesis have not been proven, we do not know what is going on with our climate, which they fail to say when making such claims. The government funded studies also claim the sun not playing a major role in our climate. I‚Äôm no scientist by any means, but that just seems ludicrous to say given that the sun literally affects everything here on earth. To me, the sun having major affects on our weather AND climate, just seems like logical common sense. But their climate prediction models show little if no interference by the sun. This is a HUGE problem with the hypothesis of human activities being the main driver of our climate. Once the models include the sun being a bigger driver to our climate over human activity, then we will finally see the true state of our climate and what it means going forward. We have a mediocre understanding of our sun and it‚Äôs cycles, but we know more about our sun than our climate, that‚Äôs for sure.

text: I wish he would expand on his answer.  His rationale seems sound but he leaves out a two key points.  First, it was a choice by the economy to go the fossil fuel route.  120 years ago Big Oil basically made sure that world would turn toward the internal combustion engine, oil was already in demand and this was a tremendous potential market for them, which stunted the growth of electric vehicles for a century.  It simply wasn't profitable or worth it to take on such a large industry.  We are only now seeing that electric vehicles are more powerful and have a much smaller long term impact on the environment.  By that I mean that it is a much more carbon emission producing process to make an electric vehicle then a gas, but you quickly see that the carbon deficit of an electric vehicle shrinks when compared to a gas vehicle running for 5 to 10 years.  I don't think its a magic bullet to fight climate change due to the way that most electricity is created, either by coal, trash burning, or oil, but its a good start to say the least.  Second, climate change is much more than rising sea levels.  Most scientists agree that it will cause widespread changes in weather pattern, amongst other things, that can lead to crop failures, mass extinctions, etc...  Try to imagine if bread all of a sudden cost $100 a loaf because there was a failed wheat harvest or if a steak cost $250 because pasture land has shrunk to almost nothing and now only the rich can eat beef.  In other words, putting it in pure eceonomic terms, its an extremely complicated issue and we do need to think about if making today's dollar is worth massive wealth erosion in the future.

Not to mention the heavy rainfall will create huge amount of runoffs that will overwhelm the drainage systems and cause massive floods. So the number of hurricanes may not increase but their intensity will.

text: ben talked about how now its just more expensive stuff in the path of hurricanes. I live in India, where close to half a billion people are dependent on agriculture for income and the rest half billion for food(meaning that rain is very important).  For thousands of years, the climate has been steady, monsoons have come at the same time every year at the right time to produce the max amount of food. But recently, monsoons have become very unpredictable in terms of amount of water and pattern. Millions of farms have failed thanks to lack of rain or too much rain. If u ask families that have been farming for many many generations, they tell us that something is actually wrong. From the pattern of insects that act as pollinators to spread seeds naturally to rain required. text:
This is a mix of some science and some misinformation here. As an ecologist, 1. pollinators don't spread seeds, linked to fertilisation from which will come seed production but don't spread seeds. 2. Phytoplankton don't produce half the worlds oxygen, big producers but not half. 3. CO2 is not a pollutant, its essential for life, no CO2, no plants, no oxygen, no life. Once drops below 300 ppm plant life suffers. A consequence of higher levels is greening of desert areas - great satellite images of this. How about we stop cutting down trees? Do we really need palm oil?  To believe CO2 which comprises 0.04% of our atmosphere drives climate is ridiculous - on atmospheric physics see the recent Connelly papers.  Whereas SF6, which is increasing exponentially in  our atmosphere & has 3000 x the warming capacity & stays in the atmosphere for thousands of years is ignored, go figure! 
Many of these activities like microplastics entering the foodweb are serious issues and man related. Unfortunately 2020 with covid have more than tripled our plastic waste. Others are natural phenomena. Things like Great Barrier Reef bleaching of coral. Wgere have coastal development increasing suspended sediment can cause bleaching  but in GBR also a natural phenomena and more related to recent El Nino events. Acts as a refresh event as scientists working on the reef will tell you.  Don't know that India has climate records that go back a century? can certainly see simarities in Europe & US with climate patterns today compared to the 1870s and 1930s.
No one likes to say it but also issues like carrying capacity to contend with. Growing populations consume more resources.  Far more complex and very much a 'wicked problem.'

text:
You insightfully mention several consequences of climate change that are true and frightening. However you mention climate stability on thousand-year and million-year scales, and the evidence just doesn‚Äôt back that up. Archeology, geology, and climatology are only just scratching the surface of the story of humanity v.s. climate.

As examples in the current literature; The emergence and dissipation of  the Harappan Civilization is completely consequent to tremendous changes in the monsoons ~3300ybp; Sea levels have risen globally by as much 120m since the Younger Drayas Glacial Maximum ~14kybp, which means that India‚Äôs costal islands were, until geologically resent times, costal mountains and high plateaus; For most of human prehistory, Sri Lanka was not an island; Evidence is emerging that the PIE migrations into South Asia were driven by desertification of the steppes north of the Caucasus ~7kybp to ~3000ybp. These are huge climate changes, with huge impact on present day India, all of which have taken place during our current Late Holocene.

It does seem that the ‚Äúcritical mass‚Äù public (think Greta et al.) are woefully ignorant of climate history (and anthropogenic climate change) on any scale that extends beyond the industrial era. It‚Äôs important  for people to know what has happened in order for people to grasp what is happening now, and that knowledge is widely lacking.

That the sun has been gradually and steadily warming, for instance. Or industrial greenhouse gasses are only compounding a 10,000 year warming period. Or sea levels have risen on average 1.2 cm per year since the Younger Dryas. Or that any reliable climate records are only a few hundred years old, and at best a statistically insignificant sample. Yes to conservation, yes to good stewardship; but when we have our children

text: Biologist here. The dangers of climate change are not really about storms, but desertification  and the  biological ramifications of change. We're in the 6th mass extinction right now. What happens when pollinators die and we run out of water to grow cops? When unusual weather causes massive crop failures? Every living thing depends on a whole delicate chain of interactions, and if you loose a vital link in the chain, the whole system collapses. Here is a very brief example.  https://www.britannica.com/topic/mutualism-1673060. What they don't mention is that these large frugivores like the agouti are responsible for seed dispersal of the large trees that make up the amazon which is one of the largest carbon stores on earth, both above and below ground. If we loose these frugivores, the rainforest can't regenerate itself.

text: People make no sense... They talk and talk about climate change, about how we have to make changes to do something about it... yet they do it while sitting at home on their computers. Climate activists go all over the world to talk about the problem then fly back home and go to their air-conditioned home. A lot of talk, but no one has come up with a remotely tenable solution for it, nor has anyone really identified either the problem or causes in any meaningful way. How much of the sea level rising is due to raising temperatures? How much is due to geothermal activities, or shifting of the earth's plates? How much is due to the changes in global economic and fishing regulations? All of these things play a part, and many more I'm sure. But how much is caused by what? We don't have the data to determine just what effects are caused by certain things, nor what the real repercussions are yet. But everyone's running around saying we need to solve the problem. The global climate is an undeniably, inexplicable complex system, that just cannot be summed up with something so simple as CO2 bad, build more solar energy. I just don't understand how people can be so closed off from the incredible complexity of the issue.

text:
Sadly to see someone who is so eloquently with his argument can still be wrong. 
- The models actually predicted climatechange pretty damn good https://www.carbonbrief.org/analysis-how-well-have-climate-models-projected-global-warming
- He states over 50% of global warming is contributle by human activity, he is not wrong with that but he forgets to state that the "extremly likely" (95%-100% probability) scenario from the same IPCC he mentioned says it is 
"IPCC‚Äôs implied best guess was that humans were responsible for around 110% of observed warming (ranging from 72% to 146%), with natural factors in isolation leading to a slight cooling over the past 50 years."
- He talks about migrating humans and when i think about how much social disturbance in the politicla and economic can be caused by just a couple of hundred thousands migrants, how about a couple of millions. He also is not mentioning the people living on Islands that sunk. First Who takes care of them and how woud you feel if someone destroying your land and says well "you can migrate".
- He talks about the Hurricans not getting stronger over the last decades. He is wrong about that hurricans are measured by their damage alone, there are changes happening that are already measurable. Here are some:
Most importantly the storms slowed down in speed which is bad as they tend to stay longer along the coast line and therefore causing much more damage and do not resolve them selfs over land as quickly. The hurricans also moved north therefore affecting other cities that arent that well prepared, in fact it happend more often than before that the hurrican was able to reach UK after going over florida. Next thing is that warmer water means more moisture and therefore the storms are wetter and causing more damage, to put it in the words of trump "they are the wettest nowadays"
- He talks about Wiliam D. Nordhaus in regards to the economist and he is actually one of the biggest advocates for good climat politics and is one of the founder of the CO2 Taxation. Here is what he had to say "Mankind is playing dice with the natural environment through a multitude of interventions ‚Äì injecting into the atmosphere trace gases like the greenhouse gases or ozone-depleting chemicals, engineering massive land-use changes such as deforestation, depleting multitudes of species in their natural habitats even while creating transgenic ones in the laboratory, and accumulating sufficient nuclear weapons to destroy human civilizations."[21] Under the climate change models he has developed, in general those sectors of the economy that depend heavily on unmanaged ecosystems ‚Äì that is, are heavily dependent upon naturally occurring rainfall, runoff, or temperatures ‚Äì will be most sensitive to climate change. Agriculture, forestry, outdoor recreation, and coastal activities fall in this category." 
So he is an advocate and has laid groundbreaking work in regards to the best economic mechanisms to apply to be most effective. On the otherhand his estimation of the costs is very flawed and he also stepped back on that matter. Basically using his function to estimate the costs our GDP would only drop by 4% if we go back into the ice age where Canada, Ireland, Scotland, northern Germany, Poland, Denmark, Norway, and Sweden were under 1 kilometer of ice. If this doesn't seem flawed to you then what does? In more complex terms: "Damage Function" should be a quadratic equation. To demonstrate this he says that since his damage function is symmetrical "it predicts precisely the same level of damage to GDP from a fall of, for example, 4¬∞C in the global average temperature, as it does for a rise of 4¬∞C." Here is more to that topic: https://evonomics.com/steve-keen-nordhaus-climate-change-economics/ 
- He talks about US leading the CO2 Emission reduction and he is absolutly right about that and that has been a tremendous success. But US also has the longest way to go but i have not doubt that this can be achieved adopting the policies that William D. Nordhaus is advocating for like CO2 Taxation or better a Cap and Trade system.
- He talks about the Paris climate change agreement he says that this is just a piece of paper that is not mandatory and he is absolutly right about that. On the otherhand let's look at what it had achieved. It basically brought nearly all countries except of 7, onto one page and to sign something. That is probably one of the most astonishing achievements within politics, think about how though it is to sign something in your own government on bipartisan base now multiply that by 188 i bet even signing that the earth is round will be a tough debate :). One other positive thing is that it in some way takes care of the global responsiblity and gives developing nations the chance to catch up and putting harsher restrictions on the developed world which helped the acceptance of climate policies around the world a lot.
But in general i am with Ben that it is not binding enough but i also see the benefits of it and that it is not black or white but grey. 
These are some of the points where Jordan Peterson and Ben Shapiro fail to apply there rationalthinking in a proper way. When you think about how well they view other topics from different stand points they seem to be off when it comes to climate policies. This might be the case in order to form a little bit of counter weight which can help improve the discussion but as laid out by Ben in this clip is actually more derailing it by building the argument on a lot of false or at least misrepresented statements.

text: Okay I sense a lot of misinformation here... first of all, in science, you don‚Äôt ‚Äúprove‚Äù anything, you find and provide evidence.  Second, global warming is still a reoccurring process.  The reason the name ‚Äúclimate change‚Äù is used more often as it describes the broader aspect of our climate.  Climate change isn‚Äôt just the gradual increase of atmospheric temperatures due to trapped solar radiation, but it‚Äôs also increasing atmospheric/marine CO2 concentration, eutrophication, sea levels rising, etc.  Fossil fuels are energy sources that formed over millions of years by means of decomposed organic material of fossilized organisms.  Where‚Äôs your evidence that that petroleum is finite?  Because it is generally known as a non-renewable resource.  Lastly, why does everything have to be a conspiracy?  Like why can‚Äôt you just accept the massively overwhelming scientific evidence that climate scientists have found over the years?  If you actually looked at some of that research, it shows a pattern that eludes to the fact that we ARE having a major impact on the rate of climate change that has spiked for the past few centuries.

This is a literal fucking bullshit conspiracy theory and I‚Äôm willing to bet that you have little to no evidence to support it.  The reason the term ‚Äòclimate change‚Äô is used instead of ‚Äòglobal warming‚Äô is because climate change is encompassed by a wide array of climate alterations that are occurring at rapid rates and affecting other climate/ecological factors, NOT because ‚Äúwe can‚Äôt pinpoint it on human influences alone.‚Äù  Regardless though, there are tons of evidence showing that recent and modern rapid climate change is occurring via human impact on Earth‚Äôs environment and our extensive exploitation of Earth‚Äôs resources.  Also, I just wanted to say that fossil fuels are NOT ‚Äúfake‚Äù - can you please explain to me why you think so?  Also, Petroleum is a nonrenewable/finite resource.  I don‚Äôt know where or how you‚Äôre getting your information, but damn.  As for solutions, nuclear and solar energy paths could very much help this issue

text: I do understand your sentiment, but unfortunately, there are many people that, even through presented with evidence that climate change is occurring, still choose to ignore it or believe that it‚Äôs some giant conspiracy orchestrated by the dEmOcRaTs.  Activists just want to bring awareness to the subject, but I totally agree that there‚Äôs a much better way to get the message across, especially while still providing sources of research.  One of the biggest issues with climate change is that it is incredible cyclical, as in the alteration of certain climate aspects will effect various climate factors, and those factors will affect other factors, and so on.  However, the primary sources that we can pinpoint are the trapping of solar UV radiation via greenhouse gases/ozone and increasing concentrations of CO2 in the atmosphere.  Currently, research has suggested that two of the biggest causes of rapid climate alteration are fossil fuel usage and deforestation.  Two solutions (I know it‚Äôs much easier said than done) is to scale back drilling for oil and mass development while having to cut down forests and woody areas.  One more specific solution is to dial back in irrigation techniques used in agriculture.  Irrigation and fertilizer usage lead to the runoff of nitrogen and phosphorus leak into streams and waterways that can give rise to harmful algal blooms and eutrophication, which will kill surrounding plants.

text: At what stage will Ben Shapiro admit an error in judgment? The reports promoted by the IPCC discussing human-caused climate change were based on faulty datasets. None of the reports based on the new datasets which included solar forcing and will appear in the 2022 summary support human causality. As an example despite lockdown due to COVID shutting down sources of CO2, temperatures have been reported as rising. The propaganda that "most" scientists agree with this narrative is also wrong. Most scientists don't speak against the narrative because of a fear of ostracism and other negative outcomes (loss of funding) if they voice their true conclusions. There has never been a poll asking all scientists anything. There was a survey of about roughly 30 people (with a vested interest) and Obama cited that result showing that 97% of those people agreed in one of his speeches setting the precedent for that misleading value. Shapiro's error in judgment wasn't his argument but the fact he placed his trust in "experts".

text: When you talk about the effects of climate change just as it gets a bit warmer and the sea gets a bit deeper it doesn‚Äôt sound that bad. There are loads of other effects you‚Äôre ignoring though such as the acidification and warming of the oceans which will kill the microorganisms at the bottom of the oceans‚Äô food chains. I question Shapiro‚Äôs assertion that storms aren‚Äôt getting more severe and that we‚Äôre just putting more expensive things in their paths. When scientists discuss storm severity it‚Äôs in terms of wind strength, size and duration, usually not damage for the exact reason he states. The other big effect of climate change is the loss of biodiversity; all of nature is intertwined and so are we in how we farm our food, fish the oceans and produce materials for clothing. This relies on fertile soil and predictable weather patterns, which only comes from the planet‚Äôs diverse plant and animal populations. We completely take for granted that we go in a supermarket and there‚Äôs food there but before the end of this century this will become something that we can rely on less and less

text:
Fast forward now to late 2020, the technology is rapidly maturing, and the incumbent auto and oil industries have been disrupted, the option to make the changes to green sustainable is economically feasible now.

Fracking very likely has consequences we're just not able to measure, but it has brought a boom to Midwest america contributing to the growing out of the great recession and reduced US reliance on a foreign conflict ridden oil for energy. Big Oil has been disrupted and is forced to sell at a loss, in the short term its an easy win.

On the other hand, the technology and infrastructure for clean energy is reaching critical mass, making the change now woult present the least resistance. EV charging networks have been built out, and about to increase en masse, texas is pioneering clean energy as it moves up the ranks in energy output. The biggest obstacle, our ability store and deploy this energy is reaching levels our brightest minds did not think possible.

China has consciously made decision to invest heavily in green energy not out of popularity but necessity. This is nation that still has a magnitude of regions to aggressively develop, their political structure gives them the advantage to make decisions it can follow through decades into the future.
author: EdYD41

text:
There is still no empirical evidence that CO2 causes global warming. (correlation does not imply causation).   An increasing greenhouse effect depends upon increased re-radiation from CO2 in the atmosphere, and this manifests itself as a tropical tropospheric hotspot, plus increased Downwelling Longwave Radiation (DLR) which warms the surface.   However, this hostspot and increasing DLR has never been detected.  In which case, CO2 is not causing global warming.

Please see my latest science paper on CO2, which demonstrates that during the ice ages CO2 was NOT controlling world temperature.  
Modulation of Ice Ages via Dust and Albedo:
https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S1674987116300305.    
Ralph.
author: Ralph Ellis

author: Geoff Evans

text:
This video was posted in July, 2019.  In 2020, the coronavirus pandemic caused all of the industrialized nations to shut down to "contain" the virus.  Regardless of your views on the shut down -- I personally consider it a massive political blunder -- it did have the effect of reducing air and surface travel by millions of people and of suppressing the gross national product of those nations.  And sure enough, urban pollution and carbon emissions feel dramatically.  If people don't drive cars or visit other people and lock themselves in their houses, they pollute less. 

But to my knowledge, that enormous drop in carbon output and demonstrably reduced pollution had no measurable effect on climate.  It seems more likely that the Milankovich cycles and varying energy output of the sun, plus other cosmic factors, have a greater effect on climate than human carbon output.  We would be much wiser to focus our environmental energies on solving problems through means that will not destroy Western economies or prevent developing countries from raising their standard of living.  Clean up the oceans and rivers, find better ways to treat human sewage, develop more comprehensive ways to recycle electronic and plastic components: all of these are technically feasible and pose no risk to our economic welfare.  Of course that does not sit well with neo-Marxists, for whom "climate change" was intended to be a means for destroying capitalism and the democracies of the West.  The virus shut down proved the folly of the "climate change" agenda, and we can now begin to discuss more rational means for improving the environment of our planet.

text:
Okay so let's unpack this. The Nobel prize winner in climate change economics said that he did not want to make dire predictions about the climate crisis, which is why the model he used is considered to be a weak one, which is against what most scientists believe today.
http://www.lse.ac.uk/GranthamInstitute/news/a-nobel-prize-for-the-creator-of-an-economic-model-that-underestimates-the-risks-of-climate-change/

Developed countries like the US and big developing countries like India and China are the biggest contributors to climate change, so it makes sense that they will have to put in the most effort. Small and poorer developing countries are actually feeling the negative effects of climate change tearing into their economy through famines and floods, and they don't have a lot of room to fight it. 
https://www.un.org ‚Ä∫ press ‚Ä∫ gaef35...
Unprecedented Impacts of Climate Change Disproportionately Burdening Developing ...

Ben says even if the sea level rises by a few inches, people will just move like they've always done. This is an understatement about the devastating impact of rising sea levels on coastal populations in poorer countries like India, Bangladesh  etc, where millions of people will be potentially wiped out. In fact, it's already happening, considering the recent devastating hurricane which hit Bengal. 
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sea_level_rise

Fishing will be impacted as a fish die out, agriculture will be affected near coastal areas and a lot of land near the coast will go underwater. Another way to understand this is, this is not about whether you eat fish or farm near the coast - this is about being comfortable with losing a huge source of food and life. It will drive up living costs for the people who survive and make it impossible for a lot of us to live, since unfortunately we only got this one planet to live on for now.

I can go on and on, but if you don't get it by now, you never will. This is a crisis, no matter how much you undersell it. This isn't about a hundred years later, this is genuinely about the day after tomorrow. If your logic for not being worried is the fact that you think it won't happen in your lifetime or it won't impact you...weeeeeelll, start by reading this comment again.

It's been about you since the beginning.

text:
From 0:33 - 0:41, Shapiro says climate modelling always over-estimated climate change. That's false; climate models have done quite well in predicting global warming, for example. Shapiro also cites the IPCC while discussing this topic. Yet even the IPCC disagrees with him on this; the IPCC, and others, note that the IPCC's model-based forecasts often under-estimated climate change:

"Evaluating the performance of past climate model projections"
"Assessment of the first consensus prediction on climate change"

"It is now nearly three decades since the first assessment report of the IPCC, and over that time evidence and confidence in observed and projected ocean and cryosphere changes have grown (very high confidence [...]). Confidence in climate warming and its anthropogenic [a.k.a. human-made] causes has increased across assessment cycles; robust detection was not yet possible in 1990, but has been characterised as unequivocal since AR4 in 2007. Projections of near-term warming rates in early reports have been realised over the subsequent decades, while projections have tended to err on the side of caution for sea level rise and ocean heat uptake that have developed faster than predicted [...] [page 1-13 in section 1.4]."
https://report.ipcc.ch/srocc/pdf/SROCC_FinalDraft_FullReport.pdf

page 86 of: "Climate change skepticism and denial: An introduction"
"Reexamining climate change debates: Scientific disagreement or scientific certainty argumentation methods (SCAMs)?"
"Climate change prediction: Erring on the side of least drama?"
"Global warming estimates, media expectations, and the asymmetry of scientific challenge"
"Comparing climate projections to observations up to 2011"
"Comparison of dryland climate change in observations and CMIP5 simulations"
"Accelerated dryland expansion under climate change"
"The Copenhagen diagnosis: updating the world on the latest climate science"


So Shapiro position is rebutted by an overwhelming about of scientific evidence on confirmed model-based predictions on climate change. That makes Shapiro a denialist. Maybe people think that's impolite to say, or find it offensive. But that's irrelevant since how impolite one finds something has no bearing on whether it's true or supported by evidence. After all: facts don't care about your feelings.

"A person who does not acknowledge the truth of a concept or proposition that is supported by the majority of scientific or historical evidence; a denier."
https://www.lexico.com/en/definition/denialist

"Sceptics are willing to change their minds when confronted with new evidence; deniers are not."
https://www.bmj.com/content/341/bmj.c6950.full
author: I I

text:
This is the height of stupidity
1 Ben claims that climate studies overestimate claims of how rapidly climate change is happening.Then he claims that the sea levels are going to rise a predictable number of inches. Which one is it? The two situations are completely different and warrant different responses. 
2 What statistics don‚Äôt back that up? What fucking statistics are you reading? Are you reading the Journal of Applied Meterology and Climatology? Have you read the papers on how temperature increases in the water lead to hurricanes having significantly more energy and destructive power? Pretty sure you won‚Äôt be knowing about any of these stats if all you read all day is the twitter feeds of anti-scientific climate change deniers.
3 Intensity of hurricanes means the energy with which hurricanes are striking the coast. Also, the path of hurricanes is notoriously unpredictable, so you won‚Äôt be building shit ‚Äúin the path of hurricanes‚Äù, unless your plan is to evacuate the coastal areas and build everything inland, which is a stupid fucking idea. 
4 Idk which Nobel Prize winner he‚Äôs talking about, but it is probably the economist Paul Romer. Idk where from his works this line has been picked from, but Romer is a known advocate for public action against climate change, and a fierce one. Shapiro doesn‚Äôt name the ‚Äòlaureate‚Äô because he doesn‚Äôt want to face heat on Twitter for misrepresenting the person‚Äôs views. Shapiro is known for twisting cherry-picked comments and has been proved several times to be a dishonest actor, so I would like to see everything he says supported by references.
5 Ben‚Äôs audience does what conservatives are known to do. They pull their pants down and bend over in the presence of the first semblance of authority, which is how a buffoon like Trump won. They have no minds of their own, so they defer the thinking part to sophists and conmen like this dude. Maybe having a college degree as a minimum standard to vote is not such a bad idea.

text:
I like that he doesn't simply dismiss scientific evidence as some other unfortunately would. 

Nevertheless, he used false information at least three times. 1) Hurricanes are becoming more intense due to climate change, not just more destructive. The science is very clear on that. Just look at the source from NASA below. Plus, the probability is high that the intensification of hurricanes has already been happening over the years. 2) William Nordhaus, the economist who won the Nobel price for his work on climate change, argues that it would be cheaper to mitigate emissions in the future, but this does not mean that - as Shapiro said - "intervention would be counterproductive." Rather, Nordhaus' paper suggests to pursue economic efficiency with the timing of your mitigation options. 3) Shapiro said "The Paris Accords were completely useless" in 3:10. Well, it is only one agreement, not several accords. But no, thats not the false information of course, as I agree it could be mispronunciation. However, he uses polarizing and politicizing language. I could now list numerous IR scholars, economist and political scientists who would argue the contrary. However, I will not engage with Shapiro's overly bold and simplistic statement. 

So, overall, it unfortunately seems to me that Shapiro is similar to most other deniers, with the slight difference that he dismisses evidence in a more sophisticated way. In any case, I believe his contribution to an intellectual debate is very limited. 



Sources: 
1) https://earthobservatory.nasa.gov/features/ClimateStorms/page2.php

2) https://web.archive.org/web/20150917214704/http://www.econ.yale.edu/~nordhaus/homepage/web%20rice%20summary%20102599.htm
3) In case you were wondering about one of the arguments how the Paris Agreement has achieved something: Liliana B. Andonova, Thomas N. Hale, Charles B. Rogeror (2018) found how the Paris Agreement has contributed positively to Global Climate Governance processes by creating a hybrid architecture through Transnational Climate Governance. Here is their book: https://www.routledge.com/The-Comparative-Politics-of-Transnational-Climate-Governance-1st-Edition/Andonova-Hale-Roger/p/book/9780815353782

text:
¬†@john smith¬† Mild climate change has benefits - longer growing season, etc., as well as downsides  - more frequent fires, etc. Mild climate change is not a major issue.
But major climate change is.
Not to get fancy on this, though, but complex systems like climate don't change smoothly from one major state to another. Change is super abrupt, and the new state is not likely to benefit lifeforms that are used to the status quo.
To give you perspective on the abrupt change thing: one moment, two cars. Next thing, a smash. One moment, a living guy, the next thing, a gunshot victim. Now, a prosperous economy, next thing, a crash. Now, a stable democracy, next thing, a coup and dictatorship. If you argue with a guy in a bar, maybe you just argue. But what if he pulls a knife and sticks you?
So this is what concerns me about climate change - we can go over the edge into something appallingly bad, and we won't know when. Seeing how close we can go to the edge, while blindfolded, is not a good idea.
author: David Franklin

text:
¬†@john smith¬† Oil? It's super valuable. But not primarily as fuel. We need cars for farms, police, ambulance etc. But for commuting, we can substitute trains, etc.
For generating electricity, nuclear and solar are rubbish, wind works great but only some places. Coal-fired stations could be converted to burning wood. Burn wood, plant trees, burn wood, plant trees. This is proven tech. So are wood-fired stoves that cook, heat water, and warm the kitchen/living space.
Oil we should conserve for medicines, plastics, etc. etc. There's a long list of materials we need that we can only get from oil (or would be hard to substitute).
Feedlot beef is a problem, but so are soy monocultures. Range-fed beef, or venison, are better options. I am pro-hunting and have hunted. And will again, given opportunity. It's a proven technology.
So I hear your concerns, but understand that I'm not proposing the nutty solutions the leftists are.

text:
On the contrary. It is you who are using false information.  Previous 10 years
2019 - 4 hurricanes = 2 major.
2018 - 8 hurricanes = 2 major.
2017 - 10 hurricanes = 6 major.
2016 - 7 hurricanes = 4 major.
2015 - 4 hurricanes = 2 major. 
2014 - 6 hurricanes = 2 major.
2013 - 2 hurricanes = 0 major.
2012 - 10 hurricanes = 2 major.
2011 - 7 hurricanes = 4 major.
2010 - 12 hurricanes = 5 major.
2009 - 3 hurricanes = 2 major.

10 year average number of major hurricanes = 3.1
The average number of major storms by decades from 1859 to 2004 is 6. (source: https://www.nhc.noaa.gov/pastdec.shtml)

If anything, past data shows a decline in major storms with cycles of above norm every 6 to 7 years. Cyclic patterns in weathers are found for anything from rainfall, tropical storms and hurricanes. What you doom-and-gloomers do is nitpick data to fit your arguments. As for your economist, I don't take advice for weather from an economist just as I don't take medical advice from a banker.

By contrary, the temporal  correlation between rise in anthropogenic greenhouse gas emissions and temperature increases, explained by the greenhouse gas effect, (Link 1 below) is evidence which has reached the scientific gold standard. With regards to the Nobel laureate economist William Nordhaus, the speaker in the video referred to him - not me. In any case, I thank you for your comment but I would ask you to NOT reply unless you have solid evidence and truly engage with my arguments.

Humans are not causing a ‚Äúsixth mass extinction‚Äù


The Amazon is not ‚Äúthe lungs of the world‚Äù
Climate change is not making natural disasters worse
Fires have declined 25% around the world since 2003
The amount of land we use for meat ‚Äî humankind‚Äôs biggest use of land ‚Äî has declined by an area nearly as large as Alaska
The build-up of wood fuel and more houses near forests, not climate change, explain why there are more, and more dangerous, fires in Australia and California
Carbon emissions have been declining in rich nations including Britain, Germany and France since the mid-seventies
Adapting to life below sea level made the Netherlands rich not poor
We produce 25% more food than we need and food surpluses will continue to rise as the world gets hotter
Habitat loss and the direct killing of wild animals are bigger threats to species than climate change
Wood fuel is far worse for people and wildlife than fossil fuels
Preventing future pandemics requires more not less ‚Äúindustrial‚Äù agriculture
I know that the above facts will sound like ‚Äúclimate denialism‚Äù to many people. But that just shows the power of climate alarmism. Plants thrive on carbon dioxide.
Scientists changed global warming to the term climate change because the climate changes. There is no global warming alarm for the alarmists so they changed the narrative. ¬†@BullseyeBullsclaw¬†  Instead of blatantly condemning people of advocating 'murder,' you haven't answered the fact and question on medical science: are you saying a person with no brain activity is alive? Ofcourse in the 7th week I myself was a potential life too, I wouldn't know any different if my mother terminated the pregnancy. It is exactly like how I wouldn't know any different if I wasn't conceived. 

And no just because you aren't alive yet, it doesn't mean you are dead- just in the same state of something that cannot be classified as alive. An egg cell (ovum) doesn't have brain activity either- so it dead, alive or neither? 

"And even by YOUR own logic, a brain dead person doesn't come to life. A human being in the womb does. At least that should give you a red flag that perhaps your analysis is faulty."
You just said 'come to life' which means you yourself agree that at the current state, it is not a life yet. 

Saying pro-choice is pro-abortion is completely ignorant. Pro-choice is having the option but not obligation to terminate, pro-abortion is terminating pregnancy at all times.
author: Ahli Nad

text:
¬†@BullseyeBullsclaw¬† Life and death is binary only under the assumption/premise that it is a life in the 7th week. The assumption is what I am questioning. 
Firstly if you knew anything on law, you cannot draw a conclusion without a reasonable and justified premise. You can't even answer a basic question determining life and death under a medical perspective, and yet you proceed to call me a murderer and think you can convince me to agree with you haha. 
A necklace is neither dead nor alive, likewise, an egg cell (ovum) is neither dead or alive- it doesn't fit the premise. 

I did not conduct any 2nd/3rd trimester abortion on myself and never on another person- so what is your point? Nice try anyway. I'm a virgin and believe in sex after marriage, but I cannot impose this on others. Do you know how many women die, knowing they have a terminal health condition and yet not having the facilities to conduct an abortion? I can easily call you a 'murderer' in that context too.

 Secondly, if you don't believe medical scientists (who know more about life and death than you do), then you should never seek medical help even under terminal health conditions. You're saying all hospitals should shut down & ppl should only resort to praying when they're have a terminal illness? Quite selfish

 I never said anything about an embryo knowing and not knowing. I was literally just answering your question on how I'd feel if I were aborted in the 7th week. So don't twist why I brought this up. (Besides, a baby does know it's being killed- obviously it can feel pain- but that's not the argument- don't dig your own grave by saying something illogical). Anyway, hospitals are allowed to remove the mask of comatose patients even though their level of have cognitive brain functioning is significantly higher than what a fetus has in 11 weeks- is this murder to you? If you admit the reason one is declared dead is because they cannot come back alive, then what does it mean to come back alive? you just admitted that the person is not alive in the current state.

 Thirdly, I'm a statistics student who knows that despite the instantaneous rate or direction of transition, if the question is asking what state is it in now? The answer should be what state it is in now. Life or not life. The question isn't dead or alive.  If you agree that life ends when a person becomes brain dead, then what makes you think an embryo with absolutely no brain activity is a life? So before using emotive language and humiliate Christianity, answer the science.

Edit: "you're supposed to be a 'scientist' who spends his limited time replying to everyone on Youtube comments, and you can't even grasp basic comprehension?"

I'm a science (statistics ) student and on holiday so if you can read, I said  I'm not a scientist *yet*. Besides you 'assumed' I was a man and proceeded to say something about me, another example of how you make assumptions and proceed to speak without questioning if the premise is true-  exactly my point.

Secondly, you said if you are not dead, you are alive-  whereas an egg cell cannot do either. You haven't answered that. I am claiming that an embryo in the 7th week is in a  similar state- it's not a life yet. Hence cannot die. Please bring up scientific arguments. 

For the last time, not everyone is Christian. When I said I wasn't christian, you assumed I was muslim. Again, you can be a non christian and non muslim and still be religious. THere are more than those 2 religions. The premise of being this or that, does not hold.

If it were a human being at conception who was dead, then that human being would be miscarried. The idea here isn't that it's merely 'alive'. The idea is that it's a human being who is alive. This isn't skin that's part of a human being that's alive because it's part of a living thing, this is an actual human being who has her own skin and her own egg cell. This isn't complex Ahli, not sure why you're unable to understand this."

I am not a medical student, I am a statistic student, who just finished my PhD, and got their approval. So as soon as the official paper work is done I'm a scientist in statistics. As part of my research for statistics, I consulted doctors, specialists and read alot of books about this- so I know.  An embryo does not have skin, please.. you're just digging your own grave.
Listen you have not answered as to why it is a life, you are just going off the context of medical science. 


 "You're saying all hospitals should shut down?" -Am I saying that? Is this how you perform your analysis as a 'medical student'?

- Yes you said god prevails science and you don't care for the scientific argument. You haven't given me any scientific argument. 

" "I never said anything about an embryo knowing and not knowing." -Yes you did. Here, let me quote you. "Ofcourse in the 7th week I myself was a potential life too, I wouldn't know any different if my mother terminated the pregnancy" "

So I was just trying to answer your question on knowing and not knowing. I never said life depends on knowing / not knowing, I was just answering your question. There was no other reason for me to mention this, without your previous question. A baby (even at 20 weeks gestation in the womb) a baby does know if you kill it- it has consciousness- if you don't know what consciousness is then I can't help. You get consciousness in the 20th week of pregnancy. But I'm talking if reflexes, without which you are medically determined to be dead. It is completely not about 'feeling' pain or knowing pain, knowing anything at all- these only come later in gestation- not at 7 weeks. There's a huge difference between reflexes and consciousness.

Do you think taking the mask off coma patients is murder? They have more cognitive brain activity than an 11th week fetus. 

"@BullseyeBullsclaw Ben speaks with very limited understanding of science. I'm a scientist and a person who is medically brain dead is declared dead [...]"
I have done my PhD on statistics. I have it approved, but I'm waiting for them to officially send the paper work to be complete. So yes, I can call myself both. I'll have my certificate in a week.
author: Ahli Nad

text:
¬†@David Franklin¬† Hey David, cold fronts are caused by an anomaly of low pressure systems coupled with ocean circulation. I specifically studied the effects of climate change between the La Nina and El Nino (ENSO) in the Pacific and North Atlantic ocean connecting Australia and North America. Since South Africa it is located in the southern hemisphere (like Australia), the frequency of cyclones are the reverse of what's measured in the North. i.e below the equatorial region, they spin in a clockwise motion, opposite to that of the North. This is because of the tropospheric walker circulation and 'density' of air. Warm air rises (near the equator) and cold air sinks causing an upwelling to result in cyclone formation.  Due to increased global warming, the formation of cyclones have become more frequent, and there is also a strong correlation for CO2 increase over the industrial revolution and global warming.  We have a strong correlation for Global warming, increased SST and cyclone activity. Btw I'm from South Africa too -I was born there, but I grew up in Australia 
 
This tracks cyclones real time:
https://earth.nullschool.net/#current/wind/surface/level/orthographic=-110.11,-53.50,1015

They take 5 year averages of cyclones hitting East South Africa- primary lit 

https://rmets.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/full/10.1002/joc.3932

This websites is in conjunction with trusted Government sites..

http://australiansevereweather.com.au/tropical_cyclones/jtwc_2009_2010_southern_hemisphere_tropical_cyclones.htm

7th week~ state which has no electrical or any brain activity, hence that of being braindead
11th week~ electrical brain activity is there, but with minimal cognitive brain activity, i.e vegatative state
20th week~ Has developed cognitive brain activity, i.e coma state 
22nd week to term~ Abortion is murder after the 20-22nd week. It surpassed the coma state 



Lastly, not everyone is Christian- we can't use god in an argument, it shows how weak your scientific argument is. 
Science helps terminal illnesses, and some (including myself) pray to god too, but not exclusively put all my faith in god and none in science, I pray and visit the docs at the same time.

text:
¬†@Torrance Desaulniers¬† The climate on earth has changed about a hundred times on earth. Climate change is a long term issue, meaning humans can and will adapt. Stop dramatizing it by portraying it as a giant storm that will kill half of the human population in one day. There's no way we can stop global warming, unless we want to completely destroy the fossil fuel industry and murder the one billion cows on earth. It's inevitable, and it makes more sense to adapt then to fight. Over time, technology will develop to slow climate change, people will build seawalls just like the Dutch did hundreds of years ago, and other solutions will present themselves when the time comes. 
An unborn baby is a "real" life. It's developed heart and lungs in the first month of pregnancy, and 10 of its major organs by the second month. Destroying a life before it's even given a chance to live is crazy and unethical. You wouldn't murder a baby after its born, although the only real difference is that its out of its mother's womb. Babies have not done anything at all in their lives to deserve this. They are the most innocent among us and least deserving of death. If you want to control birth, then there's a really easy way that does not involve murdering a baby and it's called a condom. Abortion should not be debatable at all, and there is no way you should be able to kill your child for your own convenience.
author: Bubble

text: ¬†@David Franklin¬† The main misconception of climate change is that people expect it to be a giant flooding of all of the world's coastal cities. The climate has underwent changes hundreds of times in history, and we have just adapted rather that fight it. The Netherlands is literally below sea level and has been for hundreds of years. We can build seawalls and develop technology to adapt. And I'm sure farming will still be possible with modern cooling technology.

It's unfair to the baby, and is murderous and horrifying.

I could care less of what Greta has said and instead of constructing falified information and spreading it to the public, I earnestly request you to stop. To put it simple, ice on water is different to ice on land. When 'ice on water' melts,  it only displaces as water, without increasing the volume of water- this is what happens annually. However when ice ontop of land melts, it increases the volume of sea level and it brings on the real danger. You said NASA was false, then I gave you another source and said that's false too. Why should I or anyone else believe you, when thousands of scientists who have done independent studies on this speak otherwise? Do you think they will put their jobs at stake for something like this?
I have done a kolmogorov smirnov test on this to understand how the global mean temperature has risen is proportional to the increase in cyclonic activity. Please don't misrepresent the issue by saying climate changes every day- no, the concern is the rise in climate over a threshold, not the fluctuations of daily weather conditions. It's verified that the temperature has risen by 1.5 degrees compared to pre industrial times. Also you have not and I bet you can not give an independent verified sources of your claims- your 'source' is some random sites ending with '.com' not a peer reviewed paper.
author: Ahli Nad

text:
¬†@Bubble¬† Firstly you just said it 'will be alive' after the 7th week, and then moved on to say it is murder to abort at the 7th week. The point is you cannot kill something that is not a life, so the question is in the current state at the 7th weeks is it a life? No- hence you cannot kill it. 
At the 27th week is it a life? Yes- hence you can kill it.
Before you strongly use the term 'kill' you need to know the gestation period to declare if it is even a life in the 1st place. When the premise is 'is it a life?' the answer has to be yes or no, before deciding if it is murder or not.
This is not a comparison with someone in coma, a comatose patient displays electrical synapses and minimal cognitive activity (i.e reflexes and minimal consciousness) when a fetus at 7 weeks does not have any brain activity whatsoever (no reflexes and no consciousness).  Everyone knows it will become a life in the future, but the point is at the current state at 7 weeks it is not. After it becomes a life, I am pro-life. 
Also I never encouraged anyone to take up an abortion- if everyone has an abortion we will become extinct. The point is the 'choice', the freedom to choose. I don't know of anyone who is pro-abortion, only pro-choice.
author: Ahli Nad

text: ¬†@Ahli Nad¬† If you didn't want a baby, then don't have sex or wear a condom. And you can kill a life before it becomes a life. As I said, you are destroying its future, not even giving it a chance to become a life. That is the equivalent of killing it. Just like if one cuts off a kid's leg: the kid, although not a professional soccer player yet, has lost his ability to ever become a professional soccer player. You aren't cutting his leg off while he's a professional soccer player, but the effect is the same. It isn't about when it becomes a life, it's about how it will be a life. As soon as sperm meets egg, it has the potential to become a life and can be considered a life. Even if it isn't technically a life at the seventh week (which is debatable), it should be considered and valued as a life. "Pro-choice: the freedom to choose;" but some things you shouldn't be able to choose to do, such as rape or murder of babies.
author: Bubble

text:
¬†@Markus Fischer¬† Those are great insights, I definitely think that Shapiro's over the top rhetoric is can be very polarizing and a statement like "the paris accord is useless" is a non-starter.

However, if we are going to have a discussion around whether or not we should continue to use fossil fuels, we need to approach the matter like we would any other matter; in the full context of its pros and cons. For example, let's say that I told you that there is a consensus in the scientific community that the side effects of vaccines are real. What would you say? Most likely, you would acknowledge that vaccines do have side effects but that they are far outweighed by their benefits

In speaking about fossil fuels, I would suggest it would be fair to not only talk about the side effects, but also the good that it can bring to the sake of human flourishing. For example, although CO2 concentrations in the atmosphere have gone up from about 300ppm to 400 ppm since the 1920s, and temperature has gone up about 1 degree C, the total number of climate related deaths has gone down by 99%. With the increase of fossil fuels, poor people can be fed, clothes, and sheltered at a rate that is unprecedented

Humans flourish inasmuch as energy is cheap, plentiful, scalable, and reliable to them. The side effects of what happens to the climate are FAR outweighed by the experience that humans have in the climate, because of fossil fuels

https://fee.org/articles/climate-related-deaths-are-at-historic-lows-data-show/

text: I like Ben, but the idea that hurricane frequency is the same as it has been is wrong. As temperatures increase, the ocean‚Äôs water temperature increases. The global rise of temperatures causes more water vapor to form coming from the ocean. Warm air has the capacity to hold more water vapor. Water vapor fuels hurricanes. In the 21st century, there has been a significantly larger amount of hurricanes as compared to the 20th century, most of which are higher on the scale due to the added fuel. For example, there has been more than one category 5 hurricane in 2005, 2007, 2017, and 2019.

text:
A reasonable response. I'd say he slightly underplayed the significance of global warming, however. Just like an angular difference of one degree becomes a gigantic gap over thousands of kilometres, an increase of one or two degrees across the planet can drastically affect weather patterns, sea levels and habitats for existing species, which in turn will impact on ecosystems. The human race, as he said, will be fine, and the results will not be "catastrophic", but the world will be a very different place once weather patterns become more extreme on either side of the spectrum and once species start dying out because of the effect on their habitats. 


I agree that there's no place for alarmism, but it also isn't an issue we can simply wait to deal with once its more serious effects manifest.
