text:
According to Steve Goreham, the Executive Director of the Climate Science Coalition of America, the "97% consensus" of scientists who supposedly agree that humans are a significant contributing factor in global climate change was actually only a grand total of 75 out of 77 scientists who in 2009, answered two very poorly written questions about climate change. The online "survey" was conducted by Dorran & Zimmerman. They sent the survey to 10,257 people. 3,146 people replied to the survey. 

Question #1 was: When compared with pre-1800 levels, do you think that mean global temperatures have generally risen, fallen, or remained relatively constant?

Question #2 was: Do you think human activity is a significant contributing factor in changing mean global temperature?


3,069 of the respondents answers were discarded because Dorran & Zimmerman decided that they were not actually real climate scientists, leaving only 77 respondents. Out of those 77, 75 of the people answered yes, that they believed human activity is a significant contributing factor in changing mean global temperature. That was it. 75 out of 77 = 97%. According to Steve Goreham that's where they get the bullshit number of 97% of "ALL" scientists agree.

According to Liz Wheeler, the host of OAN's (One America News) "Tipping Point, the 97% number comes from a group of "citizen scientists" aka climate change activists, who claim that they analyzed 11,944 scientific papers on the human contribution to climate change. They came to the conclusion that 97% of the scientists were in agreement. 

According to Liz Wheeler, they "analyzed" these papers simply by doing a Google search within a scientific database for the terms "climate change" and "human involved climate change". Wheeler says that they didn't actually read what the viewpoints of the scientists really were, rather, they merely assumed that those search term results meant that those scientists agreed that humans were the largest contributing factor to global climate change. Wheeler claims that a group of "actual scientists" got together and actually did analyze those same 11,944 papers and discovered that only 0.3% of those scientists actually supported the original contention of those "citizen scientists" that humans were the primary driving factor behind climate change.
https://youtu.be/i-qBOyrD0-0?t=636

The "Global Warming Petition Project" of 2007 opposed to Kyoto, which was done by the Oregon Institute of Science and Medicine, was signed by 31,478 American Scientists including 9,029 with PhD's, ALL stating that (quote) "there is NO convincing evidence that human release of carbon dioxide will, in the foreseeable future, cause catastrophic heating of the Earth's atmosphere and disruption of the Earth's climate". (un-quote)
https://youtu.be/mtHreJbr2WM?t=1713

31,478 to 75... So now... just slightly over 0.22% (less than one quarter of one percent) of scientists agree that humans are a significant factor in global climate change.

On September 23rd, 2019, A global network of 500 scientists and other professionals signed a letter sent to the Secretary General at the United Nations stating the same exact thing! Stating that (quote) "THERE IS NO CLIMATE EMERGENCY"!! (un-quote)
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GpVBH-HY5Ow

Current list of signees: https://clintel.nl/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/ED-brochureversieNWA4.pdf

The Certified Letter: https://clintel.nl/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/ecd-letter-to-un.pdf

Press Briefing: https://clintel.nl/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/ecd-press-briefing.pdf

Prominent scientists warn UN Secretary-General Guterres: https://clintel.nl/prominent-scientists-warn-un-secretary-general-guterres/

Yes, the climate IS changing. It has always changed and it will continue to change. Even the co-founder of Greenpeace, environmentalist consultant, Dr. Patrick Moore, states EMPHATICALLY that there is no catastrophic climate change occurring! 

These climate change alarmists are mostly freak'n politicians pushing this false narrative for political purposes! AOC doesn't know a damn thing about climate change or global warming! For God's sake, she was pouring drinks for a living before she won a contest to be run for Congress and some morons in her district were actually stupid enough to vote for her! Now she just parrots what her handlers tell her to parrot!  Greta Thunberg is a mentally ill child, barely old enough to get a drivers license! How the hell would SHE know anything at all about the extremely complex subject of climate change and global warming!? How in the hell are these two, "experts on climate change and global warming"!?

The obama's obviously are not at all worried about sea level rise, since they just bought an 11.75 million dollar mansion in Martha's Vineyard! text: It is really disingenuous to suddenly start raising fears about the climate causing extinction when humans have been sending animals to extinction for 300 years. Humans slaughtered 100 million sharks last year. I doubt a single shark has died from climate change. Ironically Polar bears are one of the few animals on earth who's numbers have stayed the same since they were first monitored in the 70's. That's because extinctions are caused by habitat destruction due to human encroachment not climate change. Polar bears live in hot climates in zoos around the world. The zookeepers simply feed them a diet that conforms to their habitat. A polar bear is first and foremost a bear. It can eat anything a regular bear can eat. Insects, berries, fish, eggs, small animals, and large herbivores. In the 1800's there were 100,000 tigers in the wild and 1 billion humans. Today there are 4,000 tigers and 7 billion humans. You want to stop climate change and save animals? Stop having babies. The climate isn't killing anything.
author: Anthony Morris

text: Anthony Morris yup, I know the only way to stop climate change, pollution and extinction is a significant reduction in the human population. A mass plague or a war will actually be good for earth and its other habitants. You wanna know an impact of climate change that had already happened, the Great Barrier Reef is an example. Yes, a polar bear may be able to eat anything, but throw it in a forest and it will not survive. It‚Äôs not only about food, there are other factors like camouflage. And if you think animals can all be kept in zoos and taken care off by humans, how do you like being thrown in an enclosure for the rest of your life? I‚Äôm not a crazy environmentalist, but everything he talked about only revolves around humans and our ability to adapt and I think that is very self centered as a spices sharing earth.

text: ¬†@Casey¬†   "A mass plague or a war will actually be good for earth and its other habitants."  Um, I was thinking more along the lines of family planning. LOL. I think the adaptation of animals would surprise you. In my lifetime Canada Geese have stopped flying south. That's because they didn't do this for better weather, it occurred for food. You may notice as well, that there is greater abundance of wild life within cities than there are in rural areas. Crocodiles in Africa swim around in large lakes until the dry season arrives and they end up wallowing in mud. They don't perish. Polar bears have already been seen eating other types of food and even mating with grizzly bears. The arctic fox changes from brown to white every year. Polar bear fur turns more brown as well. Numerous animals in north America live in greenery and plus 30c temps all summer, and survive in a grey or white world with no foliage in minus 30c temps during winter.

text: Climate change is not just about floods. Scientists are telling us that in order to ensure that the slow occurring feedbacks of climate change don‚Äôt happen we must keep the average global temperatures of the earth under 2 degree Celsius rise since 1990 AGT. In case that we could not accomplish that goal. We will see river fed glacier diminishing year after year till they run dry. This means unpredictable level of confusion and chaos in regions that are heavily dependent on those rivers, such as Ganges, Brahmaputra, and Sarda in India: Yangtzi, and Yellow river in China: Indus River in Pakistan. These are the bread baskets of the planet and nearly 2 billion people depend on them for crop cultivation. In addition, desertification will threaten many parts of the world due to increasing temperatures and diminishing rainfall. In places, such as the Middle East, this will further destabilizing the already volatile region and could possibly lead to military confrontation over water resources. California Central Valley, which produces 25% of food consumed by the Americans will face sever droughts and this means soaring food prices. text:
"We will see river fed glacier diminishing year after year till they run dry."  Glaciers have been melting and receding for 10,000 years. It still rains and snows. 

 "This means unpredictable level of confusion and chaos in regions that are heavily dependent on those rivers,"  It is still going to rain and this isn't going to occur over night, if at all. 

"In addition, desertification will threaten many parts of the world due to increasing temperatures"  Heat doesn't translate into desert. Ever heard of a tropical rainforest. The greatest diversity of life lives in the tropics and along the equator. How many plants and animals live in Antarctica? 

"lead to military confrontation over water resources. California Central Valley, which produces 25% of food consumed by the Americans will face sever droughts"  California is a leader in desalination. We also have pipelines and growing irrigation technology.   

"Substantial number of people from Mexico and Central America will try to enter the U.S."  They are already doing this, proving that this is an economic issue not a climate issue.  

"climate change and global warming, causing an increase in failing and failed states."  These are already failed states and it has nothing to do with climate. 

"Radical groups may gain popularity and cause civil wars"  This is already happening and has nothing to do with climate. 

"Bangladesh will be drowned,"  25% of Bangladesh has flooded for centuries. The Netherlands are below sea level and the Dutch aren't dying. These are all economic issues and nothing to do with climate.
author: Anthony Morris

text: Anthony Morris It is obvious that you have little to no scientific background. I didn‚Äôt write any of the predictions to occur overnight. Climate change have been occurring since Earths formation, but this one has been substantially influenced by human activity. Pre Industrial era Carbon concentration 280ppm, now around 406 ppm. For your record the CC ppm in the last Ice age was 180ppm. This means an increase of only 100 ppm over a period of 40 thousand years. Now how are you going to explain the jump from 280 to 406 only in the past 250 years of industrialization while it took over 40 thousand years to increase at relatively the same amount.
author: Kreev Roseworth

text:
¬†@Kreev Roseworth¬†  Whenever anyone starts a post with -  "It is obvious that you have little to no scientific background"  - it demonstrates arrogance and a lack of communication skills. When you start with an insult I just lose interest in anything you have to say. You know nothing about me. 

I'm not arguing against the belief that C02 is rising. I'm saying it doesn't matter. At 180ppm all plant life dies. Over the lifetime of the planet we are at historical lows. 406ppm is still historically and dramatically low. At record highs tropical plants existed at the Arctic circle. The largest herbivores the world as ever seen walked the earth. The entire agricultural community and even NASA are recognizing the greening of the earth. Agricultural production has been rising uninterrupted. We have desalination technology. 

You are a purveyor of a doomsday scenario. There have been millions of people predicting the end of the world but life for humanity does nothing but improve. That's what the science, data and evidence unequivocally shows. I'm a believer in the ingenuity and innovative capabilities of human kind and the human spirit. I easily refuted all of your previous comments. 

"Now how are you going to explain the jump from 280 to 406 only in the past 250 years of industrialization"  Do you know what else happened in the last 250 years? People are healthier and live longer. We've cured numerous diseases and almost eliminated starvation and poverty. We are safer, wealthier, and more educated. Life has never been better for humanity.

text:
¬†@Brett Grove¬† the fact that you think that some places getting colder is some kind of zinger just tells me that you really don't understand what we're talking about. Proponents of climate change don't pretend there aren't places getting colder. You claimed you read all the articles and yet you seem surprised by the information that you would find in these articles... I really don't think you have the level of understanding you think you have. 

Climate change predicts more extreme weather - colder in places and hotter in others. For example, a link was established between warmer artic temperatures and colder North American winters. As the artic warms, North America cools, but along with that come much harsher storms, which bring tornadoes, flooding and so on. (storms are caused by warm air meeting cold air, if you have even warmer air meeting even colder air, you get more extreme storms).

You really should actually read up on what the climate change hypothesis says if you're going to claim it's wrong. At the moment you seem to be arguing against an inaccurate caricature of the science.

You ignored both of my questions, which makes it difficult to have any sort of proper discussion. You didn't tell me what your point was, and you didn't supply a link so I can examine what you are saying about glaciers. You should probably at least try to engage with me if you are going to keep commenting. If you don't reciprocate by answering my questions, I will not continue the conversation because you aren't acting in a fair or honest manner.

author: Brett Grove

text:
¬†@Brett Grove¬† it seems to me that your understanding of the science is based on what you've seen on the news -  a very basic layman's understanding. News outlets are notoriously bad at explaining science, because they aren't scientists. If I'm one of the few you have encountered saying that the earth is both heating and cooling, you can't have read much on the subject. You have to try to understand that you really don't actually know much about this subject - your lack of knowledge is actually making you massively overestimate how much you know. As the saying goes, you don't know what you don't know. 

Here is one of a million articles that can explain it to you:
https://www.forbes.com/sites/startswithabang/2019/01/30/this-is-why-global-warming-is-responsible-for-freezing-temperatures-across-the-usa/?sh=617cf61ad8cf

As to why it was called global warming and then changed to climate change... it's a bit like why the big bang is called the big bang when there was no bang - the media like to coin a snappy phrase, and the original phrase seemed to be causing confusion so it was changed to try to help confuse people less. In addition, science is evolving - we don't necessarily understand everything about something immediately (especially something like climate - we have a ton of satellites, lots of data and experts, and we still can't always tell you what the weather will be like tomorrow). When they originally realised the planet was warming up extra fast, they didn't necessarily understand how that would affect the gulf stream. Basically, some one said "oh shit guys, we have a problem, the planet is warming too fast" and then later they realised it was having this other effect of cooling some places too. We improve our understanding with new information. 

I like that you have tried to find some data that would confirm or deny the storm issue, but don't you think that people have probably done much more in-depth studies? Because they really, really have. There are meta analyses out there you could read but frankly they would be too specialised for either of us to understand because we don't have the relevant expertise. This is complex stuff. 

Anyway, as I have pointed out several times, our amateur discussions are completely pointless.

text:
"Humans will migrate as they have done for since human beings became human beings" - Never before in human history have we had such expansive permanent coastal settlements. You cannot migrate a city, but you can abandon it when it become inundated due to rising sea levels. 

"When folks say the intensity of hurricanes has changed what they really mean is that the amount of cost associated with the hurricanes have changed" - No Ben. We mean that the intensity, as measured by the Saffir-Simpson scale which is dependent on wind speed, has changed. And indeed, if we look at hurricanes that have occurred since the Saffir-Simpson scale has been introduced, we see a greater proportion of category 4 and 5 hurricanes.

text:
Just wanted to give my perspective on sea level rising. 
I am a fisherman and my dad is also a fisherman. We‚Äôve been in the business for about 40-50 years on the coast of Maine. 

We park our boat at the dock, the dock has these markers on the wall to show the level of tide. 

If we look back to 1980 to now, the ocean level hasn‚Äôt risen in Maine. 

So this is why I don‚Äôt see what it means when people say sea level is rising. Is it rising somewhere else in the world? Because it‚Äôs not rising in Maine. 

I‚Äôm actually curious. Maybe they are talking about lake level rising from too much rain?

text:
Ben Shapiro is wrong on this topic. Really Ben, over 50% of global warming is probably attributable to human activity?!?!
It is falsely predicated on the theory that human activity causes parts per million (ppm) increases in atmospheric CO2, which is vital to photosynthesis and the production of oxygen.
This has never been proven but has only been modeled and taken as scientific fact. This is not good science.
In past geologic ages on earth, CO2 levels were higher than now when humans did not exist. CO2 is plant food and is a trace gas in the atmosphere. Water vapor with its high specific heat is the largest contributor to warming and yet paradoxically clouds are a major factor in increasing the reflectivity of heat out into space.
Carbon dioxide gas has a very high Henry‚Äôs Constant allowing it to dissolve into aqueous solution into the oceans where phytoplankton use it as plant food to make oxygen for the fish.üòä
Don‚Äôt worry...be happy. Ben Shapiro should stick to politics.

text:
Some older IPCC models underestimated the warming. As did some older reputable models. Most of them are pretty accurate. https://www.carbonbrief.org/analysis-how-well-have-climate-models-projected-global-warming. Peer-reviewed reference: https://agupubs.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/full/10.1002/2015GL064888

The increase of intensity of hurricanes in the North Atlantic since 1970 is "virtually certain" per the IPCC AR5. But attribution is less certain.

William Nordhaus is the economists' name. Shapiro was wrong about what he found. Nordhaus' Nobel prize-winning model shows 3.5 degrees C of warming is the value where costs meet the benefits, and he believes in implementing a carbon tax of about $.50/per gallon of gas immediately (EDIT: https://www.pnas.org/content/114/7/1518figure 1). Also see https://www.forbes.com/sites/howardgleckman/2018/10/10/bill-nordhaus-the-nobel-prize-climate-change-and-carbon-taxes/#46d584e6a03d.¬†

text: Shapiro grosses over the massive effect that climate change will have on ecosystems all across the world. text: During the 50‚Äôs through the early 70‚Äôs, our climate experienced a cooling. This caused many to predict that by 2050, there‚Äôd be an ice age. During the 1920‚Äôs, our climate experienced a warming nearly identical to that of which we have today. For a few years, he temperatures actually scaled themselves up 2.5 fahrenheit. Also consider the evolution of the Earth itself, and that there have been multiple  warming periods throughout its history (theoretically speaking, but also scientifically). When it started rising again, scientists went head over heals, immediately claiming the world would be a desert by 2020. (NPR, National Geographic; The latter is ironic, because they‚Äôre pro-climate change.) Perhaps we do have a role in it, but the earth itself is its own manager. text: ¬†@James Pyke¬† Actually I did hear his reply and never said that I completely agree with Shapiro. That said, ecology has more imminent pollution and human threats to land, water, food supply, and animal species than simply crying out "climate change".  Polluted rivers, overfishing, chemical contamination, and fresh water limits are only some of the more imminent problems way ahead of CO2 excess emissions. CO2 excessive emissions is a concern with a greater problem of what is the best course of correction of a multivariant problem from the beginning. Deforestation and increasing population are only two quite serious contributors to CO2 excess not directly answered with any carbon tax measure.  Where precisely would carbon tax money really go to avoid corruption of government funds and overtaxing those who pay taxes. The problem is not going to be solved by only confronting auto and industrial emissions and will never be solved by only screaming protesters who frankly do nothing constructively to help. It is not unreasonable to conclude that humanity has no consensus to a thoughtfully planned solution among all nations. Shapiro's reply was not purely bullshit as you have tried to suggest. Politicians are not going to solve this technical complex problem so much as real engineers, technicians, scientists, and innovators just like with the invention of examples like catalytic convertors, unleaded fuel, and cleaner burning power stations which helped immensely the "impossibly polluted skies". There is also truth that far more population lives near oceans which will obviously increase costs from natural flooding disasters.

I moved out of Illinois because it was getting colder and moved to Florida, where it is getting warmer. 

The climate changes, that's what it does. That's why meteorologists can't even predict local weather accurately 2 weeks out...yet these same scientists claim they can predict sea-level 50 years out?

All "Climate science" is, is attempting to establish a graph of where things are going based on where they have been, in a very short sample period of time compared to earth's history. 

"The ice caps are melting, yo ho ho ho ho hoooo!"...that was 45 years ago. 
Some of you may be too young to recall the 70's scare of "global cooling"...yes, we were headed into an ice-age back then. Then, when that didn't pan-out it became "Global Warming"....but ah, climate does not = weather...so when THAT didn't pan-out, we got "Climate Change". 

Well no shit, sherlock's, that's EXACTLY what the climate does. It changes. It took 50 years of false predictions to end up at "Temps around the globe change"....

..but now, they're back at it. OK temps are changing, which is what the PLANET does....but WE are causing it! Ha! Argue with me now!! U can't, so the solution is for government to interfere with private industry....

Ahhhh... so that was the plan all along, wasn't it "scientists who are funded by federal grants". Hmm, now what political party shouts the loudest about the climate? The one that wants the biggest government. The one that knows what is best for you, not you yourself, they know what is best for all humanity...after a 50-year track-record of being dead wrong. 

Makes sense, bruhs. Funny how the renewable sector can't even provide 10% of our energy but all those politicians invested in it the moment their party was in the White House. 
How's your mansions energy Bill's, Mr. Gore? You use more than your entire town. Oh, crap..you arent using windmills and solar but everyone else should...got it. 
Thanks for looking out for us stupid people.

text:
Ok so my first note is that I'm actually happy and surprised Shapiro isn't a climate change denier. 
But ofcourse, being a conservative, he has no understanding of the underlying reasons for climate change and how damaging it really is.
And he thinks technological progress is the solution for it. What a surprise...
First of all, human made climate change isn't some religion, you don't "believe" in it, you just acknowledge the fact of it's existence and the threat it poses to humanity.
Second of all, there were many horror scenarios and predictions, some of which didn't come true, others happened and others are happening right now. That doesn't mean you should downplay climate change, like Shapiro does. Predicting the future is just a really tough job. And climatologists aren't perfect at it.
But you don't need to be a scientist to see what's happening and where things are going.
Just acknowledge the fact that we have more and more extreme weather, we have more and more climate refugees, our earth is getting hotter, and our time to do something is limited.

text:
Marika Z - scientists pretty much unanimously agreed that the earth was flat once, and that the earth was the centre of the universe, and that mercury injections could cure your ails... need I go on? Science isn‚Äôt a popularity contest. Things don‚Äôt become true if a lot of people think it will be true, that‚Äôs not how science works. 

Think for yourself don‚Äôt let others do your thinking for you.

¬†@- 007 -¬†  If you can give me links to solid evidence to the contrary, then I'll straight up vote conservative till the day I die (I'm serious, I'll read anything you link me).  Yes, scientific fact isn't predicated on consensus, it's predicated on evidence. And the evidence provided by scientists overwhelming suggests that human being are not only contributing the the climate changing, but that we are having adverse impacts on the planet as a result. Plus, I can use my basic understanding of high school science to understand what happens when you pump CO2 in the atmosphere. So if common sense and a wealth of peer reviewed data and evidence isn't enough, then you might just be in a situation where gas companies have you tricked my dude.


Seriously, show me the actual data you're getting, not just right wing talking points from Steven Crowder and Ben Shapiro--I'm open to debate with you.
author: Marika Z

text: ¬†@Marika Z¬† I see so nothing on this earth takes this CO2 in as a nutrient and releases O2 back into the atmosphere. did your basic understanding of high school science lead you to question whether there could be such an existence on this planet? did that same understanding lead you to question whether other sources of greenhouse gas emissions could be a major contributor to long term changes in the earths climate? what does that understanding have to say about the last ice ages and warming periods? surely you don't think humans caused those.
author: 7 Sins

text:
¬†@7 Sins¬† Ok, so I'm not sure if you're trolling or not, so I'll give you the benefit of a doubt. Again, assuming that all of the research conducted on the issue and all of the data collected on the subject is completely fabricated, let's take a rationalist approach instead of an empirical one. You're aware that we're cutting trees at astounding rates, right? And that just because trees process CO2 that if you pump more CO2 into the air that the trees don't magically take in more of it, right? You're also aware of the fact that just because the climate has changed dramatically in the past (the ice age) without human contributions doesn't mean that it isn't changing THIS TIME as a result of human contributions. To claim otherwise is completely fallacious. 


All that said though, the fact remains that there isn't some global conspiracy to create a fake climate crisis: scientists across the globe have come to the same conclusions based on the evidence they've collected--and I'd strongly suggest actually reading the peer reviewed papers before enterprising them. Based on your half baked spelling, I'm guessing I'm wasting my time here, but in case you aren't trolling: I've been skeptical of climate change for a while now, but I've been able to base my opinions on the wealth of data and evidence that has been collected. People have spent their lives collecting this data, so if you think that your understanding of the data surpasses theirs, I'm sorry, but you're being exceptionally arrogant. It's ok not to be an expert at something--being humble is an important sign of maturity. Being skeptical is important--especially regarding your own positions. If CNN says the sky is blue, and they've lied in the past, that doesn't mean that there's some grand conspiracy and that the sky is actually red.
author: Marika Z

text: ¬†@Marika Z¬† doesn't prove that it is happening either. For that matter the only evidence I have seen thus far is sloppy research at best. If we are worried about atmospheric co2 concentrations then we would be far better served to quit cutting down so many trees and start planting more. Remember burden of proof is on the maker of the claim, I am simply questioning the claims of so called climate scientists.
author: 7 Sins

text:
¬†@7 Sins¬† First: debunking your claim about how "there was an ice age, ergo we are't contributing to climate change" isn't a defense of my argument so much as it is a takedown of yours--not a burden of proof fallacy at all to suggest that your opposition's argument is built on a fallacy. 


Second, so just to be abundantly clear: if I gave you 20 different solid peer reviewed sources suggesting that the earth is in fact warming and that humans are to the greatest possible degree of scientific certainty at fault, then you'd believe me? If you've only read sloppy research, then what in the bloody hell have you been reading? There are hundreds of peer reviewed studies on the subject, thousands probably, so I'm not sure what you've been looking at. 


Serious question here: if I gave you peer reviewed sources to read, would you even read them? Yes, the burden of proof falls on me, so to win this debate all I'd need to do is provide the links, assuming this is a good faith academic debate. But if I gave you all the peer reviewed evidence in the world, I get the feeling you'd call it fake. And even if you did believe what you were reading, I'm honestly not sure if you'd admit that we needed to make changes to our current system. For me to prove anything, you'd need to be arguing in good faith, and sorry, but I just don't think you're interested in the truth, and more so interested in defending the status quo under the guise of skepticism, whether you even know it or not. But hey, if you're even reading my response, I guess (taco) that proves otherwise. Guess we'll have to wait and see.
author: Marika Z

text: ¬†@Marika Z¬† not so much a defense as a doubt that THIS climate change is somehow different then the climate change that has been going on since this mud ball started spinning. You are right I do not place ultimate faith In peer reviewed studies. While I think peer review helps there are some things such as climate change where the end justifies the means so research and interpretation gets sloppy. It is possible to convince me otherwise but it will be difficult. I like my cars, my heat, and my electronics way too much to give them up on what appears to be guessing. And "green" energy sources aren't even close to being viable to handle the energy demands of my area.
author: 7 Sins

text:
¬†@7 Sins¬† I hope that this convo has been a bit of a breakthrough for you then man. In your comment, you just admitted the thing that has led you to your conclusion is not whether or not the facts about whether climate change is actually occurring, but the implications of what the existence of climate change would mean for your current lifestyle.


Please, look up what "cognitive bias" means--deeming things that you don't agree with to be "sloppy research" isn't a valid argument: you actually have to pick apart the methodological issues that you see in the studies. It's not that you don't like the idea of peer reviewed research (having experts in their fields conduct research and then having the research rigorously checked by other professions to see if the methodologies match up)--you just don't like peer reviwed research that tells you that you might have to change the way that you live.


Like I've said prior (not that you've completely read the things I've said prior): you are less interested in the facts and more interested in preserving the status quo. This is why I hate wasting my time with bad faith Youtube conservatives who can't tell a solid, sound study from propaganda from The American Enterprise Institute.


For all of our sakes, I hope you're right and that all of this "guessing" turns out to be hype--if you're wrong, then there's quite a lot at stake.
author: Marika Z

text:

If the people decide gay marriage is legal, then it becomes legal, if the people want cigs banned, they get banned. If you're willing to get you're big gun out when democratically elected officials put common sense policy in place, then that's your prerogative. Ultimately, your ideas will die in the wind through the passage of time, as the uneducated pass into the hereafter and the masses become more educated on average overall. We don't need guns: your garbage ideas will die out over time.


Again, I have blocks of peer reviewed research backing me up [I'll send it to you if you'd like to see it and promise to read any of it]: I'm still waiting for your sources, of which you have shown me none. I promise to read anything you send me, though you clearly haven't though about this issue long enough to send me anything at all.

author: peter bigo

text:
‚Äã¬†@peter bigo¬† 
If you are bored, please go hang with a friend, play with your dog, pick up a pen and start sketching. 
YouTube debates can be fun, but not as a substitute for more important stuff.
But to answer your points: not all animals eat the same diet, or can digest the same foods, or have the same gut bacteria. To compare humans with the entirety of the animal kingdom (everything from corals to kangaroos), as if there is complete uniformity, is somewhat puzzling.
As to eating meat giving you cancer: eating charred meat or processed meat massively increases your cancer risk. Any meat or other animal products that has been produced under intensive, factory farming techniques (which are hideously cruel, too), is not a good idea. I completely avoid pork and virtually all chicken meat and eggs now - I only buy stuff I'm certain is free-range. I buy kudu, springbok, eland, blesbok, etc. whenever possible, although there's still a fair amount of cattle and sheep raised on the range in SA.
Ethically-hunted venison is the best meat source, for us and for the animals under our care. Personally, I'd rather chow a springbok that lived free on the veld than chow a soy burger that was produced by in a green monoculture wasteland devoid of animals...
And not eating large quantities of plant foods, a good mix of species preferably including wild greens and large doses of sulfurous veg like onions and cabbage, is also a major risk factor. I might eat meat and eggs, but that doesn't mean I'm not eating a plant-based diet. And that doesn't mean wheat-, corn-, and soy-based.
author: Dave F

text:
¬†@Dave F¬†   I‚Äôm not sure where I compared humans with the entirety of the animal kingdom? 
However you do say you only eat/purchase free range, or ethically raised animals as if the makes what your doing kinder than those who don‚Äôt, or that it excuses you from the pain and suffering you cause every time you support the meat industry or removes your guilt as your supporting a ‚Äúethical‚Äù product, 

the key stone in ethics is to not partake in that practice if there is any doubt it‚Äôs unethical, this way your covered and have been truly ethical, you could never state that your choices are ethical as you broke the golden rule. 

You imply that free range means a good life, when in reality a free range doesn‚Äôt mean they live a long happy life, just that they have access to open space for certain amount of hours a day and die a premature death compared to their natural life expectancy.

 Venison is a red meat, less fatty but still a red meat, it does increase cancer and diabetes, as for being ‚Äúethical‚Äù maybe but sustainable no way, no meat can be raised sustainable to feed the human race at the rate we consume.
author: peter bigo

text:
¬†@peter bigo¬† Someone who thinks a predator taking another animal's life is unnatural, is someone who sees humans as separate from nature.
We. Are. Not.
I think the main reason you don't want to eat animals is because you'd like to pretend that you're not an animal. That one day you'll die, just like they do.
When I chow down on kidney, or liver, or rump, or ribs, or smiley (sheep head), or tripe - I'm well aware that I'm eating another animal. A dead one.
And one day, I'll die too.
As for the health dangers of meat: we're obviously so much smarter these days than all our ancestors throughout all the millennia. Goodness gracious, they didn't know that meat causes diabetes! They didn't even know what diabetes was! Of course, they used very little sugar, but that couldn't possibly be a factor, now could it.
As for the dressing down on "free range" and "easing my guilt", there's a reason why I've shot game myself. In massive open camps. My policy is: "one shot to the engine room, one shot drop."
If you can't see how a herd of fifty springbok on Karoo veld is better than a field of GMO soy drenched in artificial fertilizer, herbicide, and insecticide - you may already have eaten too much of that junk.
author: Dave F

text:
¬†@Dave F¬† you‚Äôve ignored the issue of sustainability, perhaps because you don‚Äôt understand what it is, and clearly as you didn‚Äôt touch on ethics I‚Äôll assume you have no idea what this means as well. 
There‚Äôs herbivores and carnivores in the animal kingdom, there all animals just because someone doesn‚Äôt eat meat doesn‚Äôt make them any less of an ‚Äúanimal‚Äù as you put it.

The difference between humans and the animal kingdom is intelligence, which is where the ethical argument comes in, we are undoubtedly on the face of it far more advanced/intelligent so using the argument that a lion eat meats is natural, is poor. 

Unless you can start to construct a half decent counter argument, it‚Äôs probably best you don‚Äôt reply as your showing your self up.
author: peter bigo

text:
¬†@peter bigo¬† As a qualified zoologist who has worked in conservation, I suspect I have a better idea of sustainability than you do. Bokkies on veld is sustainable, industrial agriculture is not.
I wrote an entire argument revolving around ethics. If I didn't use the word, it doesn't mean I didn't touch on ethical matters.
Saying that we are undoubtedly more intelligent is a very dubious proposition. Elephants and whales show at least as much intelligence as we do. And likely, a lot more wisdom. Certainly, a lot more compassion.
Advanced we may well be. We've built a global, high-tech civilisation. And trashed multiple ecosystems into utter ruin. We're burning through fossil fuels (which industrial agriculture heavily relies on), at such a rate that the question is not whether we're going to completely deplete them or irretrievably ruin the planet, but which will come first.
It's rather bizarre to submit that the very traits that have made us so utterly destructive, are proof of our superiority.
I'm sorry, but your arguments are the exact sort of lunatic fringe arguments that discredit science, conservation, and sustainability.
You're damaging the credibility of people who spend their entire careers trying to fix the mess that our species has made.
If you really want to help, start listening to people who're actually doing something. Read a few articles by Dr Gerhard Verdoorn, for example. He's contributed massively to conservation in South Africa, particularly bird conservation. He's also a hunter. Not only is there not a contradiction, the two go hand in hand.
If you don't go into wilderness, you don't appreciate it.
You don't have to go hunting with a weapon. Stalking gemsbok with a camera, or a sketchpad, or just with all your senses fully alive, and seeing how close you can come to those beautiful, skittish, dangerous grey ghosts before they spook is to become so much more intent on protecting them than sitting in front of your TV in your 500 sq foot McMansion, chowing down on a Buddha bowl, and then practising yoga very badly before drinking poorly-made green tea (hint, boiling water is a huge mistake).
author: Dave F

text:
¬†@Dave F¬† if you read what i said regarding intelligence I said ‚Äúon the face of it‚Äù that wasn‚Äôt an admittance that I believe we are more intelligent. 

Conservation as a concept is flawed, you stick an animal in captivity that will then reproduce in captivity never going to be released into the wild as nature intended. look at all the animals in conservation in Africa still high risk they will be poached. And even more unlikely that the vast majority will ever be able to reach a population of which they could be removed from the need of conservation. Instead ask your self why we need conservation in the first place? Maybe because what we do isn‚Äôt sustainable. Like I‚Äôve stated no meat is sustainable when you consume the amity we do as humans. We don‚Äôt have the land, it‚Äôs either built on, desolate or farmed. Look at any reports into sustainability and you‚Äôll find that it isn‚Äôt, just because the fancy label says it is doesn‚Äôt make it so.

The dr you mention does have an invested interest though, without the birds or animals he like to hunt, where else will he get his kicks.
You make to many assumptions, why can‚Äôt you keep into the discussion in hand rather than going on a personal attack about green tea and yoga. You discredit your own points.
author: peter bigo

text:
¬†@peter bigo¬† Zoos aren't conservation, buddy.
Vast tracts of wilderness or semi-wilderness are.
If you're going to snipe at animals in Africa being in danger of poaching, may I point out that at least we still have animals to poach?
We still have elephants, rhinos, hippos, giraffes, lions, leopards, buffalo, crocodiles.
North America doesn't have mastodons any more, nor sabretooths, nor the giant pronghorn, nor Meracinonyx, nor any camels, any indigenous horses. Wolves and bison and mountain lions are still there, but all of those came perilously close to total extinction.
As for the crack about green tea and yoga: I'm sorry. That was wrong. I was more than slightly annoyed.
In the interests of honesty, I'm no longer annoyed, because anyone who shoots down the life work of people who are committed to preserving wilderness and wild species on this planet is clearly not someone whose opinion I should remotely concern myself about.
author: Dave F

text:
¬†@Dave F¬† do you believe zoos are not conservation? They contribute research / funding towards wildlife conservation, they have endangered animals, they help with breeding for conservation breeding programmes. If it wasn‚Äôt for zoos for example the Arabian oryx would be extinct.  Your conservation parks how natural they are, just as nature intended. 

Boasting that it‚Äôs only because conservation that you‚Äôll still got animals to hunt, is bizarre. Your hunting with rifles I take it. Not exactly the same as a lion who kills its prey. The fact is you don‚Äôt have the ability to hunt of kill any animal without a tool, usually in the shape that wasn‚Äôt intended and then you believe your being ethical. 

Your own delusion has you believing your helping the situation by hunting and consuming animals. The fact is your mind set is what contributes to the demise of the kingdom not the rise. Look at the actions of you and our fellow like minded sheep, you‚Äôve already caused the  extinction of animals and put an awful lot more into dangerous level of becoming extinct. 

If you feel the need to hunt, fair enough do it, but without any tools and let‚Äôs see how you get on killing that deer or the trophy hunting. Animal on animal it Should be interesting.

text:
People need to stop worrying over the identity of what climate change is.  We need to stop clouding the truth with strange statistics.  The truth of the matter is, we are destroying the Earth through pollution, deforestation and so on.  Most days you have to wear a mask in Bangkok because the air is so polluted.  Species are going extinct because of severe habitat loss.  Ben Shapiro talks about flooding and hurricanes and so on but those are not the pressing issues. 
Why does Ben Shapiro ignore the fact that since the industrial revolution, CO2 levels has directly correlated with the increase of human technology?  I find it hard in times like these to not actively care about the planet.  Maybe climate change won‚Äôt kill us in 10 years, maybe not even in 100 but it will eventually if we don‚Äôt reduce our emissions and search for non-fossil fuel sources.

text: Just to out it short: climate change, especially carbon emissions cause positive feedback. More carbon means a faster rate at which carbon is cycled into the atmosphere. Yearly there are thousands of megatons CO2 cycled between atmos-, bio-, hydro-, kryo- and pedosphere. Humanity only emmits 4 megatons yearly. But: overall all the gains and losses of co2 in the atmosphere balance out to obly couple hundred tons increase. Humanity than adds 4 Megatons each year, increasing yearly carbon input into the atmosphere by a lot

text:
¬†@Chokladen¬† I'm interested in what happens in 50 years. 100 years. Because what we do really will matter then.
Beyond these amounts of time so much will happen politically, geographically, economically, and socially speaking that if that sea level rise is anything to go by, our actions now will have near zero impact on the future.
Short-term thinking, really, is a couple of years ahead. Tens of years up to a hundred or so is long-term thinking. Thinking in hundreds of years is brainless thinking. To think we should destabilise lives of millions now in order to make the sea levels half a meter lower in 300 years is preposterous. None of what we do now will make a change in hundreds of years.
author: abc def

text: ¬†@abc def¬† Woah dude. Climate change is SO MUCH more than sea level rise. The whole climate of the Earth will become destabilised, with more extreme drought in some areas, heavy rainfall and deluges in others. Also more hurricanes, forest fires and heat waves. Remember that the climate has never changed this fast in the whole history of our planet, except from when the dinosaurs went extinct. So there is good reasons to believe human caused emmisions will trigger a new mass extinction and make it way harder for humans to live on this planet. I'm only 18, I will live to experience much of this.
author: Chokladen

text:
¬†@Chokladen¬† I do know there's much more to climate change than sea levels rise, however, again, how will we stop climate change if the developed society where the conversations about it are taking place don't even account for half of the emissions? Is China going to play this game? Are India or the Asian and African developing countries going to play this game? If we reduce, say, the US carbon emissions to net zero, how will it impact the global climate? Will the delay in the looming catastrophe be of enough worth to cause economic harm to millions now? Is it right to show weakness now when the second cold war is brewing on the horizon potentially? The matter is so much more complex than whether or not we reduce GHG emissions. And thinking that it isn't won't do us any good.
Because future generations might suffer if you don't take action now, sure, but if you only daydream about the future you might find yourself driving your car off a cliff.
The risks are giant in any step we take. Trivialising the problem is the single most common and most harmful thing happening in the discourse surrounding Climate Change.
author: abc def

text: ¬†@wind surfer¬† Yes, I understand your claim, but you have to be aware that there was an artificial increase of the global temperature IN 1990. text: ¬†@daer devvyl¬† usually I don't respond to this type of stupidity but I will on the Black Panther intimidation one. This was first brought up under the Bush Administration who took a pass on it due to no evidence of voter intimidation. Not one person called or emailed at that voting precinct of being intimidated and not only that, the number of people who voted at that specific voting precinct increased dramatically from the previous presidential election. The Obama Administration got an injunction on them based upon the video so they actually did something and got got what they could because to prove voter intimidation you need a complaint or evidence that it effected voter turnout and they had neither. Just because a black man looks scary and may have tried to intimidate (and is a horrible person) doesn't mean they broke the law and that's why the Obama Administration was lucky to even get an injunction against them and it's why the Bush Administration dropped the case in the first place. You can say "Of course people didn't complain, they were too scared." It is possible for that to be true but in a court of law hypotheticals don't apply. Those are the actual facts of what happened but rather than admitting reality is often complicated it's easier to just say Obama didn't do anything when in fact they did and probably got a favorable ruling they didn't fully deserve regardless of how despicable those guys are.

text: Are you a climatologist?
author: mike knows

text: ¬†@mike knows¬† I have a degree in civil engineering and specialized in air pollution control. I learned a lot about climate change. So to answer your question, I'm not a climatologist, but I know a lot more than anyone that's not involved in climatology or air pollution. Definitely more than Ben Shapiro.
author: obtsfan

text:
obtsfan that‚Äôs cool. Honestly good for you, but that only adds some credibility to your argument.  Doesn‚Äôt mean ur right, likewise doesn‚Äôt mean he is wrong cuz he doesn‚Äôt have those certifications. Literally just had an LSAT question relating to this and the term used was appeal to authority. It adds a sort of licensure to what your saying but it doesn‚Äôt prove it. The strength of an argument is based on the validity and relevance of the premises used to support its conclusions - not license. His ability or anyone‚Äôs ability to understand reports and reason through them isn‚Äôt limited by their degree. That‚Äôs why theyre shown to the public so we can take a look. 

TLDR you‚Äôre basically saying if you haven‚Äôt been in the field or are not an expert you shouldn‚Äôt be listened to. Which isn‚Äôt true.  

And even if you‚Äôre saying we shouldn‚Äôt listen to someone who isn‚Äôt an expert over an expert that‚Äôs still wrong, because that expert isn‚Äôt human and being an expert doesn‚Äôt make them right.
author: mike knows

text:
¬†@mike knows¬† Yes, having a degree in air pollution doesn't mean that I'm right, and it doesn't mean that he's wrong, but it does vastly increase the chance that I'm correct relative to him. There's a reason why air pollution engineers are employed to deal with air pollution, and not podcast hosts. If you honestly think that it's a good idea to hire Ben Shapiro to calculate the quantitative effects of greenhouse gases on the atmosphere, then that's on you. Might as well hire him to design a rocket engine and a particle accelerator while you're at it, or hire me to be a lawyer or host a podcast. Formal education exists for a reason. 

But that's all besides the point. I never said that I'm correct and Shapiro is wrong because I have a relevant degree and he doesn't. He started off his own answer by saying "I'm not a climatologist, but..." He is fully aware that his views should not be regarded in the same light as that of climatologists, hence the disclaimer. That's the main reason why I started my comment by pointing out that he isn't a climatologist. 

Now if he had said something that demonstrated "the validity and relevance of the premises used to support its conclusions" then I wouldn't have had a problem with it, but instead he was literally unaware of about half a dozen effects of climate change which are readily available to anyone that is willing to do enough research. Like I said, he only lists rising sea levels and more frequent hurricanes as the destructive effects of rising temperatures. Those are not the only two effects, and it doesn't take a degree in air pollution to find reports on that. I suggest you do a Google search of each of the things that I listed if you don't believe me. You talk about reports being accessible to the public, and about not needing degrees to understand them. Then go ahead and actually read the reports. Don't just depend on a political podcast host to spoonfeed the information to you, and blindly bash anyone that provides counter evidence. 

I have no issue with listening to non-climatologists that actually demonstrate an in-depth understanding of climatology. I do have an issue with listening to anyone that claims to be correct about climate change but demonstrates a very limited understanding of it.
author: obtsfan

text:
obtsfan I get what your saying, I really do. Pointing out credentials certainly helps SUPPORT an argument but adhominem, which is the attack of the person, is almost never accepted as the main support in a serious debate. It‚Äôs really something to take into account sure mainly to the extent that you have more info and premises to call upon, but to actually go at an argument, one should attack the argument - not the argumenter. 

So like both you and he himself has stated, ill recognise he isn‚Äôt a expert in the field, but unless I find something that counters his logic or presents flaws to his argument, his conclusion is completely valid and acceptable otherwise.
author: mike knows

text:
mike knows You obviously don‚Äôt get what I‚Äôm saying. At all. And I apologize in advance for this comment but this is really frustrating.

I‚Äôm fully aware of the fallacy of ad hominem and I did NOT use that as the main support of ANY of my statements. My mentioning that he was not a climatologist was NOT my main argument, that was something that he stated AND a conclusion I drew because of his lack of knowledge on the topic. 

If you say that license and ad hominem have no place in a serious debate then why were you asking for my license or focusing on myself this whole time rather than my argument? You opened this can of worms yourself and now you‚Äôre telling me that you‚Äôre above that kind of conduct. Please. You attacked my character first. 

I‚Äôve been waiting.. HOPING that you attack my argument. I‚Äôve done a shitload of research on this topic, and I have the sources and numbers to support any of my statements. I already listed almost a dozen data-driven FACTS, which you‚Äôve ignored. I‚Äôve invited you to Google my claims to validate them, and you‚Äôve refused. For all this big talk about attacking an argument, you sure do very little of it. You‚Äôve been talking about my character vs Ben‚Äôs this whole time. 

You‚Äôre not going to ‚Äúfind something that counters his logic‚Äù if you have the same limited expertise that he does, and if you REFUSE to do any additional research. I ‚Äúpresented flaws in his argument‚Äù. If you refuse to believe me or merely fact check me, then your ignorance is to blame, not me. And this is the frustrating predicament that scientists, especially climatologists, have to deal with: trying to educate adults that refuse to listen AND refuse to look at the data. If you refuse to do either then you‚Äôre a closed system. You‚Äôve made up your mind and nothing will change it. If you‚Äôre wrong, then you‚Äôll stay wrong forever. 

This will likely be my last comment. I was hoping for a reasonable debate on climate change but you‚Äôre just going to attack me and defend Ben, no matter what evidence I bring and have brought to the table. This is pointless. I suggest you take a good look at your biases and unwillingness to do research before you do whatever you planned on doing with that LSAT, and I say that out of frustration but also because you‚Äôll benefit a lot from it.
author: obtsfan

text:
obtsfan obtsfan i wasn‚Äôt looking to debate the content lol. Was just saying that your mention of qualifications doesn‚Äôt really do much - most people don‚Äôt have the qualifications ur talking about but that doesn‚Äôt mean no one else can speak on the content relating to those qualifications. Not sure how I‚Äôm defending anyone either üòÖ - was just pointing something you said.  And from the OUTSET your first words were ‚Äúhe isn‚Äôt an XYZ, so i wouldn‚Äôt put much weight‚Äù - so it‚Äôs not hard or wrong for me to say that‚Äôs misguided thinking for anyone looking to have an intellectual discussion on something.  

That has been my focus for all my comments and I‚Äôve been fairly consistent on that. 

Not looking to debate climate change.
Wasn‚Äôt looking to defend Ben lol.
Or attack you, 

just pointing out the the would be basis for your argument (which you did support with points that would be in a debate) was a bit off kilter.  If you had taken that line out and didn‚Äôt make it look that was the main reason for why you thought he was wrong (which anyone reading it would think), I probably wouldn‚Äôt have said anything ü§∑‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è

But you have a good day! I hope you have learned from this as well
author: mike knows

text:
mike knows ok. I‚Äôm not even going to get into that. I get your point but at the same time that‚Äôs really deflecting from what my original point was, along with the facts that I brought to the table, which supported my opening statement that he isn‚Äôt a climatologist and therefore his assessment doesn‚Äôt hold much water. That was a conclusion drawn from his lack of knowledge on the topic. If he had shown that he was knowledgeable about climate change yet still held his same view then I wouldn‚Äôt have mentioned that his assessment shouldn‚Äôt be taken seriously, but he literally proved my point, and disproved your point. He is living proof that his lack of expertise in climatology is a reason to not take his assessment seriously, and I stand by that. 

And you defended him several times by saying that you had no reason to believe that his views were not valid, even after I laid out many reasons for why they weren‚Äôt valid. You also refused to look at any of the data I presented, or do any research even when I pointed you in specific directions. Your conclusion was still that Ben could be right. That‚Äôs just a clear sign of bias, willful ignorance, or both. And the only reason why you‚Äôre here is to give ME a hard time over a minor component of my opening statement? And you really think you‚Äôre impartial? Come on. You‚Äôve been detracting from my opening statement for a week now. Just call a spade a spade already. 

If I had known that I was just arguing over semantics for a week I would‚Äôve stopped a long time ago. This does not help move the climate change conversation forward in the slightest. This is just intellectual masturbation of the highest order, which I will gladly bow out of. But I appreciate that you‚Äôve been civil, and I hope you have a great day as well.

text:
¬†@AB D114¬† 
" It‚Äôs like the same reason why christanic fundamentalists can‚Äôt accept the science of evolution. "

I disagree. Your equivocation that all Christians are fundamentalists is incorrect. I am pretty confident that evolution is a well researched biological phenomena. Some Christians that struggle to accept evolution as a casual biological phenomenon is not due to not accepting the science but, all have to do with dogmatic theological Hermeneutics that churches require their attendants to believe. The theological dogma usually is due to the hermeneutics of the first couple chapters of Genesis. Which sadly the average Christian most likely has the incorrect interpretation. 

There are actually two separate creation accounts in Genesis Ch.1 and Ch.2. both accounts are actually different from one another due to differences in style, scope, and organization of the two chapters. The two creation accounts also have different literary styles, scope, and organizational principles. Genesis 1 describes the creation of the entire cosmos (heaven and earth) over six days, with repetition and patterning, climaxing with God‚Äôs rest on the seventh day. By contrast, Genesis 2 (the first chapter of the Garden story) is more straightforwardly a narrative in the formal sense, with a series of tensions and resolutions. And in contrast to the wide-angle view of Genesis 1, which surveys the cosmos as a whole, Genesis 2 zooms in telescopically on humanity on the earth. While some Christians often think of the first humans as a primordial couple, we need to balance the picture in Genesis 2 with that of Genesis 1, where God creates not individuals, but population groups to fill various niches‚Äîincluding flying creatures in the sky, swimming things in the water, and then on the land both animals and humans (the latter designated by the collective noun ‚Äôadam). Christians only read this account of human creation as an original couple because we RETROJECT the account from Genesis 2 back into chapter 1. But we need to respect the different portrayals of creation in each account. Even in Genesis 2, the initial pair that God creates are described as ‚Äúthe human‚Äù (ha‚Äôadam) and ‚Äúthe woman‚Äù (ha‚Äôi≈°≈°√¢). ‚ÄúAdam‚Äù becomes a proper name only in the genealogy of Gen 5:1 and ‚ÄúEve‚Äù is the name given to the woman in Gen 3:20. These names are clearly symbolic, since the name of the first man is ‚ÄúHuman‚Äù (‚Äôadam) and the name of the first woman (havv√¢) sounds like the Hebrew for ‚ÄúLife.‚Äù

¬†@AB D114¬† 
" Hate to tell you, but you are wrong once again about your assessments. Try again next time. "

Unfortunately, I disagree. I don't think you want a genuine dialogue by your juvenile condescending remark of "Try again next time."

It appears you also have an incorrect interpretation of the bible as well. The book of Genesis includes two very different creation stories. The first, ‚ÄúGenesis 1‚Äù runs from verse 1:1 to the middle of 2:4 (2:4a). The second, ‚ÄúGenesis 2,‚Äù runs from verse 2:4b to 2:25. Beginning in the 18th century, European Old Testament scholars discussed this point in earnest. The next two centuries brought the discovery of numerous creation stories from ancient Mesopotamia, Egypt, and Canaan. With the discovery of these creation stories, scholars could now see clear evidence to support a nonliteral reading of the Genesis texts, since each biblical story shares characteristics of different Near Eastern stories. the ancient Jewish interpreter Philo of Alexandria (20 BC to AD 50) understood Genesis 1 and 2 to be contradictory. This was not a problem for Philo, however. Rather, it signaled to him that the two stories were not meant to be understood historically. God meant them to be understood as pointing to realities deeper than the merely historical. The two creation stories are not saying the ‚Äúsame thing,‚Äù nor does Genesis 2 follow chronologically from Genesis 1. They are two distinct stories of creation, both in terms of content and order. They cannot be harmonized‚Äîthey were never intended to be. Genesis 1 speaks of the mass creation of humans (male and female) at one time by the collective noun ‚Äôadam. Genesis 2 begins with one man, then one woman from the man in a separate act. The difference in vocabulary reflects the difference in perspective. 

Clearly, Genesis chapters 1 and 2 are separate accounts. It appears that your interpretation is as dubious as that of a fundamentalist.

text:
¬†@AB D114¬† 
" What you call, "circular" psychologists call truth. " 

No. It's not called "truth" it's called faulty logic.  Since your statement is reliant on circular reasoning there's no reason to believe the statement is true. What a sloppy talking-point on your end. 

" The bible, for example, is not proof of the existance of God. It assume the existance of God. " 

No one said this... This is a strawman talking-point. Science also relies on assumptions as well. The process of building scientific knowledge relies on a few basic assumptions that are worth acknowledging. Science operates on the assumptions. Assumption (#1) There are natural causes for things that happen in the world around us. For example, if a ball falls to the ground, science assumes that there must be a natural explanation for why the ball moves downward once released. Right now, scientists can describe gravity in great detail, but exactly what gravity is remains elusive. Still, science assumes that there is an explanation for gravity that relies on natural causes, just as there is for everything in nature. Assumption (#2) Evidence from the natural world can be used to learn about those causes. Science assumes that we can learn about gravity and why a ball falls by studying evidence from the natural world. Scientists can perform experiments with other falling objects, observe how gravity affects the orbits of the planets, etc. Evidence from a wide range of experiments and observations helps scientists understand more about the natural causes of gravity. Assumption (#3) There is consistency in the causes that operate in the natural world. In other words, the same causes come into play in related situations and these causes are predictable. For example, science assumes that the gravitational forces at work on a falling ball are related to those at work on other falling objects. It is further assumed that the workings of gravity don't change from moment to moment and object to object in unpredictable ways. Hence, what we learn about gravity today by studying falling balls can also be used to understand, for example, modern satellite orbits, the formation of the moon in the distant past, and the movements of the planets and stars in the future, because the same natural cause is at work regardless of when and where things happen. Science and Religion are reliant on axioms... so what? This isn't controversial.

text:
¬†@AB D114¬† 
No. you actually don't even know the difference between fact, theory, hypothesis, and law...  

Fact:¬†Observations about the world around us. Example: ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs bright outside.‚Äù 

Hypothesis:¬†A proposed explanation for a phenomenon made as a starting point for further investigation. Example: ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs bright outside because the sun is probably out.‚Äù 

Theory:¬†A well-substantiated explanation acquired through the scientific method and repeatedly tested and confirmed through observation and experimentation. Example: ‚ÄúWhen the sun is out, it tends to make it bright outside.‚Äù

Law:¬†A statement based on repeated experimental observations that describes some phenomenon of nature. Proof that something happens and how it happens, but not¬†why¬†it happens. Example:¬†Newton‚Äôs Law of Universal Gravitation.

Neither one are the same. Gravity isn't a fact, it's a well-grounded theory. Laws can't explain why phenomena happens.

author: Ian C

text: Noelle butcher yeah that is how the system works generally, but you did not explain why CO2 is a GHG. CO2 absorbs long wave radiation. The Earth emits infrared radiation which GHGs, like CO2, absorb and reemit as heat in a directions. Essentially the energy from a photon is absorbed by CO2 causing the molecule to vibrate and collide with other molecules then releasing the energy. With this happening with so many molecules, the molecules gain speed causing a rise in temperature. The most significant GHGs are H2O, CO2, CH4, N2O, and O3. The strongest, or most potent, GHG is Sulfur Hexafluoride followed by HFC and CFC gases.

Based on the findings, they summarize and present the results. I've been looking through the shortened version for policy makers: https://www.ipcc.ch/site/assets/uploads/2018/02/AR5_SYR_FINAL_SPM.pdf)


"Assessment of many studies covering a wide range of regions and crops shows that negative impacts of climate change on crop yields have been more common than positive impacts (high confidence)." Page6


"It is likely that the frequency of heat waves has increased in large parts of Europe, Asia and Australia." P7


There are likely more land regions where the number of heavy precipitation events has increased than where it has decreased. Recent detection of increasing trends in extreme precipitation and discharge in some catchments implies greater risks of flooding at regional scale (medium confidence). P8



A large fraction of species faces increased extinction risk due to climate change during and beyond the 21st century, espe-cially as climate change interacts with other stressors (high confidence). Most plant species cannot naturally shift their geographical ranges sufficiently fast to keep up with current and high projected rates of climate change in most landscapes; most small mammals and freshwater molluscs will not be able to keep up at the rates projected under RCP4.5 and above in flat landscapes in this century (high confidence). Many terrestrial, freshwater and marine species have shifted their geographic ranges, seasonal activities, migration patterns, abundances and species interactions in response to ongoing climate change (high confidence). P6

text:
Some older IPCC models underestimated the warming. As did some older reputable models. Most of them are pretty accurate. https://www.carbonbrief.org/analysis-how-well-have-climate-models-projected-global-warming. Peer-reviewed reference: https://agupubs.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/full/10.1029/2019GL085378

The increase of intensity of hurricanes in the North Atlantic since 1970 is "virtually certain" per the IPCC AR5. But attribution is less certain.

William Nordhaus is the economists' name. Shapiro was wrong about what he found. Nordhaus' Nobel prize-winning model shows 3.5 degrees C of warming is the value where costs meet the benefits, and he believes in implementing a carbon tax of about $.50/per gallon of gas immediately (EDIT: https://www.pnas.org/content/114/7/1518figure 1). Also see https://www.forbes.com/sites/howardgleckman/2018/10/10/bill-nordhaus-the-nobel-prize-climate-change-and-carbon-taxes/#46d584e6a03d. Also see https://policyintegrity.org/files/publications/ExpertConsensusReport.pdf, and philipsphilosophy.wordpress.com for more information.

Nice try there, Ben. A swing and a miss.

author: chris banda

text:
Chandler Moore he said 50% of warming. I am majoring in BioRenewable Systems at Penn State so I‚Äôm totally biased towards renewable energy and I think I can chime in on this. We don‚Äôt need to hurt the economy to develop sustainable solutions to our problems. We can make renewables profitable and applicable in places like Africa and China. We don‚Äôt need to ban oil, but the number one thing you can do that will help us move forward is to recognize how the food you eat and the products you use not only impacts the environment, but how it gets in the way of developing sustainable solutions.

A large amount of the US landmass is used for grazing animals and providing feed for them. Estimates are upwards of 45% of our land. How can we invest in renewables like solar wind and biomass when we‚Äôre willing to buy a steak that took an acre to produce for $15? Just planting the overworked or overgrazed fields alone with large perennials or trees would absorb years worth of carbon and provide products such as biomass, healthy food, wildlife, clean air and filtered water, and an abundant source of the worlds best building materials out there. I challenge you to think about what you can do and not what your government can make it‚Äôs people do.

text: Yes, but as a biologist, Shapiro's answer is way off the mark, yes different weather will cause problems, but by way of massive crop failures and loss of suitable cropland due to desertification. However.. the real ramifications of climate change are biological. It has already put us into the 6th mass extinction,  with insects being hardest hit so far. That doesn't sound too bad until you realize that Insects include pollinators and one of every 4 bites we eat is from a flowering plant that requires pollinators. Every living thing depends on a whole chain of interactions and once you loose an important link in the chain, you get whole system failure. Im posting a link to a good, brief example of this, but what the article doesn't mention is how large frugjvores are mainly responsible for rainforest regeneration. If you loose the orchid, the bee, or the frugivore, you loose the rainforest because the tree cannot reproduce. If you loose the bee, the trees are also functionally extinct and 6ou loose the forest.

text: ben talked about how now its just more expensive stuff in the path of hurricanes. I live in India, where close to half a billion people are dependent on agriculture for income and the rest half billion for food(meaning that rain is very important).  For thousands of years, the climate has been steady, monsoons have come at the same time every year at the right time to produce the max amount of food. But recently, monsoons have become very unpredictable in terms of amount of water and pattern. Millions of farms have failed thanks to lack of rain or too much rain. If u ask families that have been farming for many many generations, they tell us that something is actually wrong. From the pattern of insects that act as pollinators to spread seeds naturally to rain required. There are too many pests and natural anti-pests have decreased so they have to use a lot of chemicals that might cause poisoning. Climate change does have actual ramifications across the world right now. Its just starting. and its gonna get much worse. Its a chain process where acid rain might kill small insects on the ground which reduces the number of natural pollinators so trees become less and less. therefore herbivores become less. food for carnivores and top of the food chain becomes less and including destroying of their natural habitat is upsetting the entire system that was stable for millions of years. We dont see it. phytoplankton produce half of earths oxygen. they are very small and live in the ocean. Now we all wear synthetic fibres. there micro-plastics when washed end up in the ocean and kill our major source of oxygen and we dont even know about it. Coral reefs are like the major cities and are the economic hub of the oceans. 80% of them are all dead. The entire  ocean ecosystem is changing. If Our climate increases by even 1degree Celsius, ocean patterns change and result in change of climate, fish mating patters leading to a huge drop in fish. Millions of fishermen and the economies of a lot of small countries collapse first then the big countries will come

text: ¬†@alan mac¬† I'm sorry but you are wrong. Everyone who is a climate change denier and don't think humans are causing it are just uneducated and wrong. If you look throughout geological time, yes there has been warming, however that warming is due to things like  the earth moving on it's axis. "Global Warming Has Begun" was the article on the front page cover of the NYT in 1988, we have known about this problem for years and it's not just going to go away because you don't believe in it. Watch Our Planet & Blue Planet by David Attenborough, it's a great and interesting way to learn about how ecosystems are being effected on Earth. We are in the middle of the 6th mass extinction on earth and ecosystems are collapsing across the world due to habitat loss from warming and other human activities. If entire ecosystems collapse such as the oceans, then the "economy" doesn't really matter because the entire world will start to collapse. I don't know where you got that statistic about how "95% of the CO2 emitted is from natural sources" from because is just wrong, but even if it wasn't it doesn't make any point. Carbon is cycled though the atmosphere, lithosphere, hydrosphere and biosphere every day in hugh quantities, and what humans are dong is ADDING CO2 TO THE CYCLE, so your bullshit percentages don't even show the full picture that the 95% of carbon from last year might be a fuck tonne more than the 95% of carbon today. No person who starts off an argument against human-caused climate change begins with "I am a climate scientist", and Ben Shapiro actually starts his argument off with the complete opposite because is doesn't know anything. The truth is out there man, and 98% of scientists agree that humans are warming the planet. If we fuck this up, then in 100 years you'll look back and think to yourself "fuck, I was wrong, and now the planet is going to be fucked for 1000+ years, my bad, should have listened to the people that actually knew what they were talking about..."

text:
Carbon dioxide (CO2): Fossil fuel use is the primary source of CO2. CO2 can also be emitted from direct human-induced impacts on forestry and other land use, such as through deforestation, land clearing for agriculture, and degradation of soils. Likewise, land can also remove CO2 from the atmosphere through reforestation, improvement of soils, and other activities.
Methane (CH4): Agricultural activities, waste management, energy use, and biomass burning all contribute to CH4 emissions.
Nitrous oxide (N2O): Agricultural activities, such as fertilizer use, are the primary source of N2O emissions. Fossil fuel combustion also generates N2O.
Fluorinated gases (F-gases): Industrial processes, refrigeration, and the use of a variety of consumer products contribute to emissions of F-gases, which include hydrofluorocarbons (HFCs), perfluorocarbons (PFCs), and sulfur hexafluoride (SF6).

Based on the above analysis, the total global anthropogenic GHG emissions are currently estimated to be around 36.2 Gt CO2-eq per year. Given the lack of sufficient volcanic data and research, and without considering seismic emissions, natural system emissions are estimated to be approximately 18.13‚Äì39.30 Gt CO2-eq per year, with a most likely value of 29.07 Gt CO2-eq per year. Hence, the total annual global GHG emissions range approximately between 54.26 and 75.43 Gt CO2-eq. The ratio of natural to anthropogenic emissions ranges between 0.5 and 1.09, with a most likely ratio of 0.8. This shows that anthropogenic and natural GHG emissions are of the same order of magnitude. Anthropogenic GHG emissions account for approximately 47.9%‚Äì66.6% of the total global GHG emissions, with a most likely value of 55.4% (Fig. 2). However, if the GHG emissions from volcanic eruptions and earthquakes are included, the natural GHG emissions are likely to exceed anthropogenic GHG emissions.
Advances in Climate Change Research
