author: Andrew M

text:
Ben Shapiro. The master of logical fallacy.


"...The water level is going to rise a rather predictable number of inches, or feet and then Humans will migrate based on those weather patterns..."

Fallacy #1 - False dichotomy
Either "Terrible Catastrophe" OR "Sea Levels Rise, NBD..."
I'm pretty sure that there's a gray area here. Ecosystems that humans rely will be affected. Mass migration creates civil unrest, infrastructure can't always adapt quickly enough. There's potential for a significant death toll.

"Storms are becoming that more severe, they're doing that much more damage, the statistics really don't back that up. What they really back up is that we're just building more stuff in the path of hurricanes..."

Fallacy #2 - False attribution
The dollar amount of damage caused by hurricane does not determine it's intensity.
Why would he cite statistics of damage cost? It's irrelevant. Do you really believe that the NOAA would measure the intensity of a storm based on the cost of damage? Storm intensity is based on it's energy output, and guess what? They are increasing in intensity.

"What level of climate change requires what level of cut-backs in terms of the global economy"
Fallacy #3 - Loaded question
Question contains the assertion that climate change solutions require cut-backs in the global economy.
Not true. Economies can adapt and thrive to a new green market. Including developing countries.

"It's a complex issue and all the folks that are basically like, 'Let's just kill capitalism', good luck with that."
Fallacy #4 - Straw man

All those folks huh? All those imaginary folks in Ben's head that want to kill capitalism.

You can find logical issue with most of the stuff Ben Shapiro says. I have no idea how he's been able to make a living with his mouth diarrhea for so long.


You may want to read up on these.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_fallacies

¬†@Ugo¬† Do you actually know why scientists say billions of years? It's based on things like rock strata, decay of radioactive isotopes, stars moving away from each other (observable in the present), fossils, entropy, etc.

So: why does your computer work? Why do you listen when the doctor says you've got a bacterial infection? Why do you trust a plane, a train, an automobile? Why do you think you can get food from a farmer, if he/she is getting advice from evolution-based agricultural science?
And for the record, I'm a born-again Christian who loves Jesus.
These are not incompatible.

text:
THERE IS NO CLIMATE EMERGENCY !!


https://clintel.nl/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/European-Climate-Declaration.pdf




https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GpVBH-HY5Ow




10 simple points of dealing with climate change


1. Climate is changing and always has - we need to adapt as we always have


2. Man contributes something to the change process - how much is not known because the models don‚Äôt match observations


3. Trying to stop it is too expensive, we should work on adaptation as we have since all of history


4. There is a political agenda to control people by controlling the air and water via money -  the whole issue has been hijacked


5. Higher CO2 is likely to increase food production - PC incorrect to say this; also water vapour (eg. cloud) is the biggest influencer of climate (warmer = evaporation = clouds = reflection of heat -- thus self regulating)


6. Warmer has been better for humanity historically


7. Minimising pollution and wasteful consumption is a good thing, but not to the point of sending is back to caves.  Yes we should plant more trees, reduce our impact, invest in genuinely useful technology that reduces pollution, but stmopping plastic straws when China, India, the continent of Africa account for around 90% of the waste in the seas is pointless virtue signalling.


8. The hypocritical hyperbole of the screaming left is not helpful, Using 16 year-old children to emotionally blackmail lies is beyond comprehensible


9. Nuclear needs to be brought online as base load electricity


10. Renewable are too expensive and represent a false economy (e.g. cost of a wind turbine vs its generated power, also the pollution cost in building a turbine [steel and other components]) - ditto electric cars; their total impact pollution is too great


Our best strategy is adaptation (like always) with reasonable mitigation of pollution in general.

text:
¬†@Xavier Cockerton¬† At some point in the course of evolutionary history we had to evolve from amphibian-like creatures. When water both makes up the majority of the earth's surface and is necessary to live, it really doesn't make sense to lose the ability to breathe under water. Considering that natural selection is the key driving-force behind evolution, with survival of the fittest being the goal, of what benefit is gaining the ability to drown? Maybe generations of ancestors avoided water at all costs so that it was no longer necessary? It's senseless in any context.

The cornerstone of evolution is based on a logical impossibility: giving what you don't have. All mutations result in either duplicate information (like an extra finger) or a loss of information (missing a limb). There are no mutations that add anything new to the genome. You'll never see a human born with a wing because no human has that information to pass down. All change is a scrambling of pre-existing information and the different combinations are what produces the variety we see. This process also inevitably leads to a loss of information with traits that are never passed down. We aren't getting more complex and diverse. We're losing it. Evolutionists look at the fossil record and say "look at where we came from!" I say, "look at what we lost". The theory is the exact opposite of what is actually happening, but I know it's the best theory our brightest minds can come up with to avoid any mention of a Creator. A for effort.

text:
Oh god, this is ridiculous. 97% of scientists agree not only climate change is real, but humans are responsible. 

And what solution is Ben offering here? If the water rises, litteraly every costal town will either partially or completely be flooded. So instead of preventing that, he suggests people move when the land is no longer inhabitable? 

Orlando is predicted to be flooded by the rise of the sea level. They have 280 000 people there, also disney world and universal studios.  Where are you gonna put these people? Not to mention they can't exactly sell their homes, who would buy flooded homes? So climate change will make 280 000 people basically homeless and with no prospect. And that's just one town. If nyc is affected, you'd have 8 million people in need of new homes. Not to mention global economy would collapse if the city is submerged. 

And this just the us coast, the entire world would be affected by rising sea levels. 

Is taking drastic action economically profitable? Not initially, no. But down the line, it would absolutely be. 

Think of it this way. You're out of shape and some random guy comes at you with knife. Now, suddenly sprinting might make you extremely uncomfortable, you might feel dizzy, run out of breath, no one would argue that simply walking away will be more pleasant. But sometimes, you just need to sprint and stop thinking about it. In the end, your survival is more important than your comfort. Climate change is real, and the consequences will be horrible. It's time to do something about. Put regulations on companies, throw away less, recycle more. Use less water in the shower, stuff like that. If Ben's solution is to do nothing and then move if your house is flooded, then fuck him.

author: Ridge Caples

text:
Hydroelectric brings a challenge considering it will only be useful once the government has built the infrastructure nessasary, ie dams which are by no means cheap and also potentially damaging to the environment.

Nuclear has it's own problems considering how the plants required to harness fission energy are not only expensive, but complicated to built. Thry also take years to built, about 10, which is cutting it in terms of the deadlines we must meet.

Solar however, is still an emerging technology and is already close surpassing some fossil fuels in price. An emerging market has also grown as a result, (salt betteries) which are the solution to the lack of power at night which is predicted to be responsible for 10% of the world's power in the coming decades. 

Overall, I think solar is the best and most obvious shot we have since it is within the grasp of the free market and requires less government initiative.

text: Up until now, I have avoided the comments section of Ben Shapiro's videos because I'm not a big fan and I've seen the backlash of critical comments but time and again I hear Ben speaking about something he knows little to nothing about, thinking he can sway the crowd if he speaks fast enough. Arrogant and asinine, Ben depicts an exaggerated science fiction movie, goes on to cherry pick climate science all while dismissing the idea that climate change is due to human activity. Misunderstanding the information, Ben greatly underestimates the increasing threat of human induced climate change. Sadly Ben, it's not just a couple of inches of oceans rising, a few degrees hotter weather, and people moving over land. All life would be dramatically effected, most notably agriculture being destroyed by erratic extreme weather and thus reduced food yield. Plant die offs would also effect medicinal industry hard. The environment is so delicately balanced that once one thing goes, it makes it easier for other things to go and chain reactions take place. All industries would be hit hard because they generally all depend on the environment, it's a chain reaction.  The economy would suffer insurmountable damage so that economics guy you were talking about will need to find a new job. I could go on and on about the many disastrous consequences we know will occur if something isn't done to curtail human induced climate change sooner than later because at a certain point, it will be too late. Perhaps though Ben Shapiro, you should've stuck with your original statement, " I'm not a climatologist". That's all I got for now folks, let's see how many dislikes this gets among you all, haha.

text:
Chad Keogh quit claiming your pseudoscience as fact. The truth is we are speeding the process of climate change up. There is more than enough evidence out there supporting this phenomenon. I do not understand how so many Americans deny it, it‚Äôs baffling and terrifying.

The Paris accord was a step in the right direction as it promoted countries working together to solve an issue that ultimately affects us all - something which until then had been approached independently by different countries.

Ben Shapiro uses this absurd argument that because third world and developing countries won‚Äôt stifle their economic growth to deal with climate change means we shouldn‚Äôt - instead we should be offering financial aid to those developing countries who are willing to protect their environments and impose sanctions on countries unwilling to do so.

Sure, we can all say this issue won‚Äôt affect us in our lifetimes but that is no philosophy to live by - and for some of us, especially those living in major cities or by the sea, issues like air pollution and rising sea levels will affect us - if they are not already.

text:
Justin Wordell anecdotal evidence is just as useless as it has always been friend. We‚Äôve already seen warming seas lead to the loss of 80% of the Great Barrier Reef, the reductions in fish stocks around the world and a rise in sea levels. We‚Äôve seen more volatile weather patterns and hotter summers. This may seem like nothing to you, but this is what we‚Äôve managed to do in just 100 years since the industrial revolution.

And then you have to realise that our emission have been steadily increasing since then - the rate at which, globally, we are dumping co2 into the atmosphere is only increasing as more countries industrialise.

But regardless it‚Äôs not me you should be listening to. There are countless research papers you could read and plenty of experts saying the same thing. To deny them is to claim some sort of mass conspiracy that benefits absolutely nobody. In my opinion, to do so is purely selfish - it is a convenient excuse to ignore the lack of care a government or organisation shows towards the health and wellbeing of the population.

I am constantly shocked by the number of Americans supporting ignoring the issue of climate change when it is not them who benefit from doing so - it is the oil and gas company‚Äôs, coal burning power plants, polluting car manufacturers and other corporations who benefit from not having to curb their emissions - ordinary people just suffer.

text: ¬†@Matsab¬† i think it would be incorrect to think that i think we should ignore it. Idk if you are familiar with nikola tesla, but hed tried his entire life and ended up successful in creating a natural energy grid that harnesses earth energy and hydroelectricity to generate power that could be distributed globally, wirelessly and just using a tower or series of towers that he dubbed, the wardencliff tower. Alas, it never came to fruition because of greedy and dishonest people like JP morgan and Edison. Thankfully today, in 2019 there is a functioning (to my knowledge) 'model' of teslas tower in texas, located at a electricity company by the name of viziv technologies. They have been testing and researching this tech to see if they can bring it to the market, but hopefully, it potential is able to deconstruct the market and make life for everyone easier by generating world wide free power. Tesla was an extraordinary genius, has over 300 pattents and our technology derives mostly from his technological contributions, he also had basic plans to create anti gravity propulsion systems using the energy from the wardencliff towers hed planned to have globally. In theory, this would help eliminate combustion engines, which would result in less of an increase of fossil fuels. Then, we can focus on fixing our contribution to climate change since we wont be contributing to it as much. But there is a LOT of greedy people today and folks who dont want that to happen, that will prevent us from progressing. We have a lot to fix before dumping trillions of dollars into a mostly a nation wide decision to eliminate all carbon emissions by 2020. And quite frankly, im of the opinion that there is still an whole lot more to learn about the climate in general before we decide to go tweaking it. There is an undoubtable and overwhelming amount of (and you can fact check this if you dont go to nasa.gov\climate,, and actually look at institutions researching this like the university of columbia, U.georgia and many others) published peer reviewed articles that suggest the end of the ice age resulted in major global catastrophe that resulted in the mass extinction of over 100 megafaunal and floral species WORLDWIDE. The scale of this scenario dwarfs this current climate change but we cant quite figure out what caused it. Some scientists have a decent idea of what it was but we cant be certain. But looking back in time at fossil records, ice core samples and what not just over the last 500,000 years, we see major catastrophes happening cyclically, on different scales in size but they are there and more common than previously imagined. We have a lot to learn, to change and to fix, but it starts within the people, and the people we can trust.

text: ¬†@Peter Piper¬† Except that there is literally no evidence and reason to believe in any particular religious book, be it Bible, Quran or whatever else, it's just blank statements wich have no basis in reality. Why do you believe in bible and not in some Hindu books that say that earth is rotating on elephants back, why? Why don't you believe in Zeus, you have no less reasons for that than for believing in Bible or any other books. Religious books can only be studied and valued from historical, sociological or psychological view. To believe in them blindly and without doubt is just bullshit and disgraceful to your own brain and reason. Wanting something to be true doesn't make it that way. Evolution is based on many many archeological and molecular evidences, and years and years of research and hard work. And than you some random guy think you can discredit it just because it contradicts some of your non evidence based dogmatic views.

¬†@Peter Piper¬† The problem I have with your view is that it has absolutely zero evidence. You might be right who knows? Chances are you are not. The theory of evolution has evidence to back it up, you don't. And to your point about slowly gaining intelligence, a couple hundred years ago we didn't have toilets and shat in buckets or whatever. Now we have toilets and internal plumbing. Lets not forget we have a numerous other things such as cars, phones, internet, computer etc. All of this intelligence gained over a period of a couple hundred years. Imagine the stark contrast there must between humans from a thousand years ago.... a million years ago. What do you think about fossils of our ancestors that are strikingly different from current human morphology? They have features that closely resemble the morphology of other species. Clearly the human morphology has been gradually changing over long periods of time. What about DNA evidence that shows the shocking similarity between us and other species like apes? Point is, the theory of evolution has irrefutable evidence and you don't. You just have a book of sayings uttered by someone who had a "revelation."

author: CaneFan423

text: ¬†@Can Conservative¬† Yes, you are right that CO2 makes up a very small percentage of the atmosphere. 99% of our atmosphere is made up of oxygen and nitrogen, and both of these gases cannot absorb infrared radiation from the sun. Of the gases that absorb infrared radiation in our atmosphere, CO2 and water vapor are the most prevalent (these gases are what keep the earth warm and without them the surface temperature would be close to zero degrees). So even though CO2 exists at  very small concentration in the atmosphere, it is one of the only gases that absorbs infrared radiation and changes the temperature. Both CO2 and water vapor are two of the major gases responsible for absorbing heat, but CO2 levels are changing at a much higher rate due to burning of fossil fuels. Does this answer your question? I am not really a conservative or liberal, rather I come from a more scientific viewpoint. Therefore, I'm more versed in talking facts than policy. Also, this information comes from the director of Columbia University's Cooperative Institute for Climate Applications and Research article on one of their journals.

author: Matthew Curiel

text:
‚Äã¬†@Matthew Curiel¬† I'll respond to this point because I think it's a good one: 
"But i make my point to say that isnt good reasoning to do nothing and continue things as usual because you dont know for a 100 percent FACT that a projection of an event that hasnt happened yet is false as you say till we go however many years to the day things are projected to happen and yes it might not be 100 percent but anything over 50 percent accuracy is fucked"

I have two rebuttals: 
1. Nobody proposes doing nothing. Sometimes people who lean left claim that the absence of government intervention = nothing, but that's not true. Without government intervention, people's choices will still change over time. For example, as people get richer, they tend to have less children, so as the world gets richer that's what's predicted to happen. Also, as people get richer they can afford to care more about the environment. But my main point here is that we shouldn't confuse the absence of government intervention as current trends extending into the future.  

2. I don't know what you mean by "things are projected to happen." It really matters what you mean because if we don't know what we're referring to, we can't have a coherent conversation around solutions. And I think that's part of what makes a lot of people roll their eyes. It's not just that we don't know what the accuracy of these estimates is, but we don't even know what the potential event is. I understand that your position is "even if there's a 50% chance of there being a catastrophic event, we should prepare for it" and I agree. However, it depends on how catastrophic the event is and what it's going to be. One annoying thing that climate change activists often do (and I'm not accusing you of this) is they say "we need to do something" but they seldom make any specific recommendations for specific problems we're going to face, which makes it hard for everyone else to take them seriously.

text:
You do realize we can do both right? 


If we don't kill ourselves first, then climate change will .

he problem with climate change and the leading cause of it (Greenhouse gases like CO2) toxifies rain water that gets into our plants, foods, drinking waters etc. Especially our oceans and the animals in it (animals we tend to eat). It doesn't take a scientist to know or test it out (Just your basic college chemistry) that CO2 breaks down with water (H2O) to create Carbonic Acid that releases excess hydrogen ions from the chemical reaction that eventually forms bicarbonate which is a form of carbon that does not leave the ocean easily.  

Now the ocean does a good job of releasing CO2 thru natural process, but we've been creating excess CO2 that scientists have noticed a change and obviously creating more bicarbonate and carbonic acid. The increase in CO2 (Carbon Dioxide) and Bicarbonate lowers PH levels (Meaning it makes oceanic water more acidic) which in hand kills ocean life like plankton, reducing food for whales, fish, etc and at some point reducing our supply of fish as well. 

I can go into very in depth details about this, but you can do you own research and this is honestly only one example of the effects of global warming/climate change, but the media and liberals only focus on that headline, which is sad, but not as sad as climate change deniers.

text:
Turtle Game.  Do you understand how these ‚ÄúClimate Crisis‚Äù ‚Äúscientists‚Äù arrive at these conclusions?  It‚Äôs a hypothetical modelling system.  Its not based in actual fact.  

All they have done in 30 years is created an ash pile of failed predictions.  In approximately 180 years of record keeping the earth has warmed by a grand total of 0.9*C (+\- 0.2*C). 

The Climate models basically break the world up into a grid and everything from cloud cover to sun radiation, wind patterns, ocean oscillations, etc etc etc are input into the model.  They have very little information of this depth for each section.  At absolute best they 180 days of data (which is more realistically maybe 40 days max) for each day of the year.  

Man made Climate change, or at least the ‚Äúcrisis‚Äù they pretend it to be is complete BULLSHIT.  The IPCC is BULLSHIT.  The UN is BULLSHIT.  All designed to extract money from poor people in rich countries and redistribute it to rich people in poor countries.  Nothing more.

text:
The problem with climate change and the leading cause of it (Greenhouse gases like CO2) toxifies rain water that gets into our plants, foods, drinking waters etc. Especially our oceans and the animals in it (animals we tend to eat). It doesn't take a scientist to know or test it out (Just your basic college chemistry) that CO2 breaks down with water (H2O) to create Carbonic Acid that releases excess hydrogen ions from the chemical reaction that eventually forms bicarbonate which is a form of carbon that does not leave the ocean easily.  

Now the ocean does a good job of releasing CO2 thru natural process, but we've been creating excess CO2 that scientists have noticed a change and obviously creating more bicarbonate and carbonic acid. The increase in CO2 (Carbon Dioxide) and Bicarbonate lowers PH levels (Meaning it makes oceanic water more acidic) which in hand kills ocean life like plankton, reducing food for whales, fish, etc and at some point reducing our supply of fish as well. 

I can go into very in depth details about this, but you can do you own research and this is honestly only one example of the effects of global warming/climate change, but the media and liberals only focus on that headline, which is sad, but not as sad as climate change deniers.

text:
I find it odd that Mr. Shapiro identifies as a philosophical realist, yet accepts the claims of evolution. It's amazing that evolution is seen as a complete empirical fact when in reality it is simply a naturalistic philosophical interpretation of scientific data. Naturalists see that change occurs, therefore they presume that this change means that the nature of a creature can turn into another, radically different creature provided enough time is inserted into the equation. There has been no observable proof of a transitional form nor has any proof been found in the fossil record outside of mere speculation. And when species are found which exhibit aberrations, these species never reproduce and in most cases are infertile. The most reasonable version of the evolutionary hypothesis is that of creatures suddenly appearing in new forms in the fossil record, but this again does nothing to explain the transition of non-living matter to living matter beyond the hand-waving of "time" or "primordial soup" fantasies.

There are fundamental issues with the PHILOSOPHY of evolution, which many have been trained to believe as irrefutable scientific FACT simply because those who dissent from the status quo are silenced or denigrated as "pseudo-scientists" or "creationists."

text: ¬†@I am ONE of MANY¬† - It is one thing to think about the definition of something and it is another thing to nuance that definition in the context in which a word or phrase is used. Take African-American as an example. The term does not technically mean from Africa and in America. African-American contextually means black. It means someone who is of the African race. That term is often applied to someone who has never been to Africa. However, a white person whose family has lived in Africa for hundreds of years, if that person moved to the United States, would not be considered African-American. That's the nuance of social context. That nuance explains how one can be of a particular religion even though he or she does not adopt all the tenents of that religion. That nuance is very different than someone saying something is white when something is really black. There is a clear understanding of what black and white mean. Just as is there is a clear understanding of what male and female mean.

text:
¬†@DigitalLog0s¬† ¬† No, you're completely if you think people's philosophical beliefs coincides  with their discoveries

You're also wrong about there being no observables evidences. (I'll provide short proofs, if you want the overwhelming evidences, I recommend you read On the Origin of Species)

1. We can actually observe evolution happening in the lab and in nature. Biogeography is another form of evidence. There's also molecular evidence of common descent; you can compare the genes or proteins of different species and see how they are related, which ones were inherited from common ancestors. An example of that is that humans have 23 pairs of chromosomes, while other apes have 24, and our 2nd chromosome is actually the result of fusion of two chromosomes which exist separately in other apes.
Consider the three following angles to evolution by natural selection (I'm assuming your question is about that, rather than the broader "evolution" as change in Nature, which is the question we seek to explain):
2. At its core, Darwinian evolution, the natural selection, is a mechanism. It posits that under certain basic selection conditions and traits that are heritable via a gene (practically the DNA in biology, though can be defined more broadly). The first doubt is if the natural selection, wherein the gene is randomly changed not changed in any specific direction, actually can generate the phenomena we observe, disregarding exactly how the gene is manifested. In other words, a question if an algorithm/mechanism actually can produce the outcome we know. This mechanism can be studied quite nicely with computer simulations. This obviously simplifies the matter greatly, and allows scientist to study the mechanism in itself. Especially with respect to complex phenomena, like cooperation between non-kin individuals, has been quite fruitfully studied with simulation. In fact, some of the residual debate around the finer details of evolution, are studied with mechanistic simulations. There is a lot of literature on evolved cooperation, see [for example this](https://deepblue.lib.umich.edu/bitstream/handle/2027.42/62686/414441a0.pdf?sequence=1&isAllowed=y). In short, you can say that these studies provide evidence that certain observed phenomena are not contradicting the natural selection process but indeed can be an outcome of it. Of course, it does not prove that these natural phenomena must be produced by natural selection, however.
3. When we observe an animal or plant that seems very fit to an environment, a consequence of the natural selection idea is that we arrived there through gradual change of previous individuals in said environment. Because evolution takes time over multiple generations, we rarely have distinct ancestors and descendants to compare side-by-side (with exceptions, see next point). Therefore, taking current species that are related by common ancestors of different separation in time, and investigating their similarities and differences should provide a somewhat gradual progression if evolution by natural selection is true. The evolution of the eye is one area that has been fought over a lot, where the critique has been that something that complex just cannot have been gradually formed over time. You can [read briefly about that here](https://www.nyas.org/magazines/autumn-2009/how-the-eye-evolved/). Something related in kind is the study of the genetic code of proteins. Through so called multiple sequence alignments it is possible to quantify the relations between proteins. Again a favourite counter-example to evolution are proteins that take part in a type of pairwise interaction, where the argument is that evolution could never produce both necessary changes without an intelligent designer guiding the changes, because natural selection would have to be gradual, one mutation at a time. So one genre of evolutionary studies is to discover generations of related proteins and show how in fact the complex interactions are reducible to individual mutations, see this [key study for one example on mitochondria](https://www.pnas.org/content/pnas/106/37/15791.full.pdf), and its [popular scientific summary here](https://www.wired.com/2009/08/reduciblecomplexity/).
4. The issue with the former point is that it is all based on retrospective data analysis. It is always possible to be very critical of this and argue that other mechanism are just as possible, and that at best one is showing there is consistency in the theory and current observations. The fruit fly has become a favourite tool to overcome this criticism, because the fruit fly has very short life, so in a reasonable amount of time scientists can study how a fruit fly population evolves to some laboratory defined condition. You can read a brief summary of one long study of [fruit flies living in darkness here](https://www.nature.com/news/flies-reared-in-the-dark-for-60-years-give-up-their-genetic-secrets-1.19339). Bacteria is another example where evolution can be studied in real-time. Generally one can then analyze how controlled environmental conditions lead to the proliferation of certain traits, which then can be traced to their genetic and protein antecedents. Of course fruit flies are one very simple species, so one can always be doubtful about how well findings in them translates to more complex animals. However, as noted in [this nice article](https://www.theguardian.com/science/2017/oct/07/fruit-fly-fascination-nobel-prizes-genetics), as many as six Nobel Prizes have been awarded to research on fruit fly.
